This is a list of flags used in the modern state of '''[[Greece]]''' or historically used by Greeks. ==National flag== {| border="2" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 1em 1em 1em 0; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse;" |- bgcolor="#efefef" ! width="110"|Flag!!width="80"|Date!!width="300"|Use!!width="300"|Description |- | [[File:Flag of Greece.svg|140px|border]] || in use since 1822 (as naval ensign), and since 1978 sole national flag. || The current [[Flag of Greece]] was adopted by the [[First National Assembly at Epidaurus]] in January 1822 as the naval ensign. Between 1822–1978, this flag was used at sea and for foreign service. In 1978, it was established as the sole national flag and also as the war and civil [[Ensign]].|| Nine equal horizontal stripes of blue alternating with white. There is a blue canton in the upper hoist-side corner bearing a white cross. |} ==Presidential Standard== {| border="2" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 1em 1em 1em 0; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse;" |- bgcolor="#efefef" ! width="110"|Flag!!width="80"|Date!!width="300"|Use!!width="300"|Description |- | [[File:Flag of the President of Greece.svg|140px|border]] || since 1979 ||Distinguishing Flag of the President of the Hellenic Republic ([[President of Greece]]). Used to show the presence of the President of the Republic (in vehicles, buildings etc.). This flag also used as a [[Maritime flags#Other flags|Rank flag]] in the [[Hellenic Navy]]'s ships mainmast when the President of the Republic is aboard (according to Article 45 of the Constitution the President of the Republic 'is the symbolic head of the Armed Forces' so as Rank flag this flag is regarded as similar to the flag of an [[Admiral of the Fleet]] or superior).|| A blue square flag bearing at both sides a silver coloured cross with equal arms and a tip formed in the middle of the lower end of the vertical arm. Τhe areas adjoining to the cross have the same colour with flag, the cross bounded with a golden coloured line forming an escutcheon which totally surrounded by two golden coloured laurel branches forming circle, intersecting under the tip in cross. (A form of the [[Coat of Arms of Greece]]) The Flag is produced in four sizes (1st 1.70 m (5.58 ft) sides, 2nd 1.10 m (3.61 ft) sides, 3d 0.65 m (2.13 ft) sides and 4th 0.23 m (0.75 ft) sides). |} ==Military flags== {| border="2" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 1em 1em 1em 0; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse;" |- bgcolor="#efefef" ! width="110"|Flag!!width="80"|Date!!width="300"|Use!!width="300"|Description |- | [[File:Naval Jack of Greece.svg|140px|border]] || since 1822 || Jack of the [[Hellenic Navy]] || A square flag with a white cross on a blue field. A golden crown was added in the centre during the periods of monarchy (1833–1924 and 1935–1973). |- | [[File:Hellenic Navy Masthead pennant.svg|140px]] || || [[Commissioning pennant]] ({{lang-el|Επισείων Πολεμικού Πλοίου}}, i.e., "Warship Pennant") flown by all [[Hellenic Navy]]'s ships and establishments in commission, unless displaced by a senior officer's [[Maritime flags#Rank flags|rank flag]].|| "Warship pennant, blue coloured, has shape of isosceles triangle elongated, bearing a white cross near the base of the triangle". The flag has typically base to length (height of triangle) 1 to 20. The cross has arms width 1/5 base length and each arm length 3/5 of base length. The pennant flown on the top of mainmast. |- |[[File:Hellenic Army War Flag.svg|140px]] || || [[Colours, standards and guidons|Army War Flag (regimental colour)]] ({{lang|el|Πολεμική Σημαία Στρατού Ξηράς}}) || A square flag with a white cross on blue field with image of Saint George. |- |[[File:HellenicAirForceFlag.gif|140px]] || || [[Colours, standards and guidons|Air Force War Flag (regimental colour)]] ({{lang|el|Πολεμική Σημαία Πολεμικής Αεροπορίας}}) || A square flag with a white cross on blue field with image of Archangel Michael. |- | [[File:Naval rank flag of the Prime Minister of Greece.svg|140px|border]] || since 1956 || Rank flag of the [[Prime Minister of Greece]] aboard Hellenic Navy vessels. || Like the Hellenic Navy jack, with three white rising diagonal stripes in the first quarter. |- | [[File:Flag Minister of Defence of Greece.svg|140px|border]] || since 1956 || Rank flag of the Greek [[Minister for National Defence (Greece)|Minister of National Defence]] aboard Hellenic Navy vessels. || Like the Hellenic Navy jack, with three white rising diagonal stripes in the first quarter and three descending stripes in the fourth. |- |} ==Regional and municipal flags== {| border="2" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 1em 1em 1em 0; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse;" |- bgcolor="#efefef" ! width="110"|Flag!!width="80"|Date!!width="300"|Use!!width="300"|Description |- | [[File:Flag of Greek Macedonia.svg|140px|Flag of Macedonia|border]] || 1980s {{cite book |last= Znamierowski |first= Alfred |title=The World Encyclopedia of Flags |publisher= Anness Publishings |year= 2010 |isbn= 978-1-84476-895-0}} || Flag of the northern Greek region of [[Macedonia (Greece)|Macedonia]]. Also the flag of the regions of [[Central Macedonia|Central]], [[East Macedonia|East]] and [[West Macedonia]]. || Blue field with the golden [[Vergina Sun]] in the centre. The flag is unofficial but widely recognized in Greece.{{cite book | title=Greek flags, arms and insignia (Ελληνικές Σημαίες, Σήματα-Εμβλήματα) | language=greek | author=Eleni Kokkonis-Lambropoulos & Katerina Korres-Zografos | year=1997 | publisher=E. Kokkonis-G. Tsiveriotis | isbn=960-7795-01-6}} |- |[[File:Thessaly-region-flag.svg|140px|Flag of Thessaly|border]]|| 2010s || Flag of [[Thessaly]] region|| |- | || 1995 || Municipal flag of [[Athens]]{{cite web|url=http://www.crwflags.com/fotw/flags/gr-at-at.html#ath}} || The flag is blue with an inner gold and outer red border, like the flag of the region of Attica. A white [[Greek cross]] lies in the middle, charged with a disc with a white border featuring gold [[olive]] branches. The blue disc in the center features the head of the goddess [[Athena]]. |- ||| || Municipal flag of [[Piraeus]].|| |- | [[File:Flag of Thessaloniki.svg|140px|border]] || || Municipal flag of [[Thessaloniki]]. || Dark blue with a stylized depiction of the city's main landmark, the [[White Tower of Thessaloniki|White Tower]], and an ancient [[Macedon]]ian coin depicting [[Alexander the Great]]. |- | [[File:Flag of Patra.svg|140px|]] || || Municipal flag of [[Patras]] || The seal of the city of Patras on a dark blue background. |- | [[File:Flag of Chania.svg|140px|border]] || || Municipal flag of [[Chania]]. || The seal of the city of Chania superimposed on the old land flag of Greece, with the words "ΔΗΜΟΣ ΧΑΝΙΩΝ" (''Municipality of Chania'') on the bottom right and left quadrants. |- |[[File:Flag of Rethymno.svg|140px]] | |Municipal flag of [[Rethymno]] |The seal of the city of Rethymno (two dolphins) on a teal background. |- | [[File:Flag of Heraklion.svg|140px|]] || || Municipal flag of [[Heraklion]] || The seal of the city of Heraklion on a cyan and white background. |- | [[File:Flag of Rhodes Island.svg|140px|]] || || Municipal flag of [[Rhodes (city)]]|| The seal of the city of Rhodes, depicting the head of [[Helios]], on a blue gray background. |- | [[File:Flag of Sparti.svg|140px|]] || || Municipal flag of [[Sparta, Peloponnese|Sparta]] || The seal of the city, depicting a stylized ancient helmet, on a cyan background. |- | [[File:Zakynthos flag.png|140px|border]] || || [[Flag of Zakynthos]] island. || Dark green with an orange depiction of [[Zakynthos (person)|Zakynthos]] with the island's motto "Freedom needs virtue and courage" (''ΘΕΛΕΙ ΑΡΕΤΗ ΚΑΙ ΤΟΛΜΗ Η ΕΛΕΥΘΕΡΙΑ'', from [[Andreas Kalvos]]' ''The Lyre''). |- | [[File:Flag of Corfu.svg|140px|border]] || || Municipal flag of [[Corfu]] . || The flag of [[Corfu]] has a dark red/maroon/purple large outer border, a dark gold thin inner border and a very dark blue field with the seal in the centre in dark gold. The seal shows an ancient Greek Corfiot sailing ship. ΔΗΜΟΣ (Municipality) is written above the seal, ΚΕΡΚΥΡΑΣ (of Corfu), below the seal. The flag, on which the image shown above is based, had a ratio of 11:19 |- | [[File:Flag of Paxι.svg|140px|]] || || The flag of [[Paxi]] island || A trident, traditional emblem of the island,surrounded by two dolphins on a blue and orange fond. ΔΗΜΟΣ ΠΑΞΩΝ (municipality of Paxi) is written at the base. |- | [[File:Flag of Kastellorizo.svg|140px|border]] || 1821 || The flag of [[Kastelorizo]], used as an ensign for ships from Kastelorizo during the [[Greek War of Independence]], now a municipal flag. || |- | [[File:Flag of Hydra.svg|140px|border]] || 1821 || The flag of [[Hydra island]], used as an ensign for ships from Hydra during the [[Greek War of Independence]], now a municipal flag. || |- | [[File:Flag of Psara.svg|140px|border]] || 1821 || The flag of [[Psara]], used as an ensign for ships from Psara during the [[Greek War of Independence]], now a municipal flag. || White cloth bordered with red with a large red cross and the inscriptions of the motto ''[[Eleftheria i Thanatos]]'' (Liberty or Death) in capital red letters. The cross is standing on an upside down crescent, symbolizing the [[Ottoman Empire]], flanked on one side by a lance, on the other by an anchor, around which is coiled a serpent eating a bird. |- | [[File:1821 Flag of Spetses.svg|140px|]] || 1821 || The flag of [[Spetses]], used as an ensign for ships from Spetses during the [[Greek War of Independence]], now a municipal flag. || |- ||| 1821 || Flag of [[Agistri]] island || |- |[[File:Flag of North Aegean.svg|140px|Flag of North Aegean.|border]]|| 20?? (Before 2017) || Flag of the [[North Aegean]]|| |- | [[File:South Aegean Region flag.svg|140px|Flag of the South Aegean.|border]]|| 20??(before 2017) || Flag of the [[South Aegean]].|| |- |[[File:Sterea.Ellada.jpg|140px|Flag of Central Greece.|border]]|| 20??(Before 2017) || Flag of [[Central Greece (region)|Central Greece]].|| |- |[[File:region.Epirus.jpg|140px|Flag of Epirus|border]] || 20??(Before 2017) || Flag of [[Epirus (region)|Epirus]].|| |- |[[File:Flag of Western Greece.svg|140px|Flag of West Greece|border]] || 20??(Before 2017) || Flag of [[West Greece]].|| |- ||| 2017 || Flag of [[Ionian Islands (region)|Ionian Islands]].|| |- |[[File:Flag of Thrace district.png|140px| Flag of Western Thrace|border]] || 20??(Before 2010) || Flag of [[Western Thrace]].[http://www.1uptravel.com/flag/flags/gr-local.html#thr Τοπικές σημαίες της Ελλάδας | 1uptravel.com] || |} ==Historical variants of the national flag== {| border="2" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 1em 1em 1em 0; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse;" |- bgcolor="#efefef" ! width="110"|Flag!!width="80"|Date!!width="300"|Use!!width="300"|Description |- | [[File:Flag of Greece (1821).svg|140px|border|Popular revolutionary flag]] || 1770s–1820s || This design appeared in the 1769 uprising, based on older patterns. Used among others by the Kolokotronis family, this flag, with variations, was the most widely used throughout Greece during the initial stages of the [[1821 revolution]]. || A blue or cyan cross over a white field. |- | [[File:Greek merchant navy flag.svg|border|140px|First Merchant Navy Flag]] || 1822–1828 || First flag of the [[Greek Merchant Navy]], adopted in January 1822. In 1828 it was discontinued, as it was decided that the cross-and-stripes naval flag (today's national flag) should be flown by both military and merchant ships. || Blue flag with an inverse state flag on the canton (Blue cross on white field). |- | [[File:Flag of Greece (1828-1978).svg|140px|First National Flag of Greece|border]] || 1822–1970
1975–1978 || In January 1822, the [[First National Assembly at Epidaurus]] adopted this design to replace the multitude of local revolutionary flags then in use. Since 1828, this flag was flown inside the country, while the current flag was flown on naval vessels and abroad. || White cross on a blue field. During the periods of monarchy (1833–1924 and 1935–1973), a golden crown was often added in the centre of official flags (see examples below). |- | [[File:Naval Royal Standard of Greece (1833-1858).svg|140px|Royal standard during the reign of King Otto|border]] || 1833–1858 || Royal standard for use on ships during most of the reign of King [[Otto I of Greece|Otto]], adopted in 1833. || The flag consists of the plain cross version of the national flag in 10:7 proportions, with the Bavarian arms of the [[Wittelsbach]] dynasty superimposed in the center of the cross, topped by a crown. The blue color is of a lighter shade than usual today. |- | [[File:Naval Royal Standard of Greece (1858-1862).svg|140px|Royal standard during the late reign of King Otto|border]] || 1858–1862 || Royal standard for use on ships during the late reign of King [[Otto I of Greece|Otto]], adopted in 1858. || The flag consists of the plain cross version of the national flag in 3:2 proportions, with the Bavarian arms of the [[Wittelsbach]] dynasty superimposed in the center of the cross, topped by a crown. The blue color is of a lighter shade than usual today. |- | [[File:Naval Ensign of Greece (1833-1858).svg|140px|Naval ensign for military vessels during the reign of King Otto|border]] || 1833–1858 || [[War ensign]] at sea during most of the reign of King [[Otto I of Greece|Otto]], adopted in 1833.[http://www.et.gr/idocs-nph/search/pdfViewerForm.html?args=5C7QrtC22wG-pNmgvR9663dtvSoClrL8Iqk9pJn1S_jtIl9LGdkF53UIxsx942CdyqxSQYNuqAGCF0IfB9HI6qSYtMQEkEHLwnFqmgJSA5WIsluV-nRwO1oKqSe4BlOTSpEWYhszF8P8UqWb_zFijFfWxdMZuoXTlEeBZpB1JDpNqDXzIlccWkzSE8gY-HcQ Royal Decree of 4/16 April 1833, published in ΦΕΚ 21/1833] || The flag consists of the naval version of the national flag in 25:18 proportions, with the Bavarian arms of the [[Wittelsbach]] dynasty superimposed in the center of the cross, topped by a golden royal crown superimposed in the canton. The shade of blue is undefined, but was usually of a lighter shade. |- | [[File:Naval Ensign of Greece (1858-1862).svg|140px|Naval ensign for military vessels during the late reign of King Otto|border]] || 1858–1862 || [[War ensign]] at sea during the late reign of King [[Otto I of Greece|Otto]], adopted in 1858.[http://www.et.gr/idocs-nph/search/pdfViewerForm.html?args=5C7QrtC22wFt6lurlHBlsXdtvSoClrL8b5S2mIvi-NjtIl9LGdkF53UIxsx942CdyqxSQYNuqAGCF0IfB9HI6qSYtMQEkEHLwnFqmgJSA5WIsluV-nRwO1oKqSe4BlOTSpEWYhszF8P8UqWb_zFijK93wwqKt6r-Pg1JjKMaDLXcLIGKGfcVTjGoLIJZ-mHk Royal Decree of 28 August 1833, published in ΦΕΚ 41/1858] || The flag consists of the naval version of the national flag in 3:2 proportions, with the Bavarian arms of the [[Wittelsbach]] dynasty superimposed in the center of the cross, topped by a golden royal crown superimposed in the canton. The shade of blue is undefined, but was usually of a lighter shade. |- |[[File:Greek Royal Flag 1863.svg|140px|border]]|| 1863–1913 || Royal standard reported during the early years of King George I's reign.FLAGS AND SIGNALS OF ALL NATIONS by Hounsell Brothers c.1870 http://www.life.com/image/50700092Greek National Historical Museum {{cite web |url=http://www.nhmuseum.gr/details2.php?lang=1&wh=1&the1id=1&the2id=7&the3id=69&theid=69&open1=1&open2=7&open3=69&thepid=185&lang=2 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-01-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721082725/http://www.nhmuseum.gr/details2.php?lang=1&wh=1&the1id=1&the2id=7&the3id=69&theid=69&open1=1&open2=7&open3=69&thepid=185&lang=2 |archivedate=2011-07-21 |df= }} || Swallow-tailed Greek flag and the Coat of Arms of House of Glücksburg. |- | [[File:Standard of King George I of Greece (1863-1913).svg|140px|Personal flag of King George I of Greece|border]] || 1863–1913 || Standard used by King [[George I of Greece]]. || The flag consists of the plain cross version of the national flag, with a [[Coat of arms of the Kingdom of Greece|Royal Coat of Arms of Greece]] superimposed in the center of the cross. |- | [[File:Royal Standard of the Kingdom of Greece (1914 pattern).svg|140px|border]]|| 1914–1922{{citation needed|date=November 2017}}
1935–1936 || Royal Standard of the King, adopted in 1914.[http://www.et.gr/idocs-nph/search/pdfViewerForm.html?args=5C7QrtC22wEpPcAGqWYddHdtvSoClrL8r_t-tPq24FR5MXD0LzQTLWPU9yLzB8V68knBzLCmTXKaO6fpVZ6Lx3UnKl3nP8NxdnJ5r9cmWyJWelDvWS_18kAEhATUkJb0x1LIdQ163nV9K--td6SIufxyD1yiVq2Y-uUQ1UR3EOYxVVeeioiYBuL_IKxURr0- Royal Decree of 3 June 1914, published in ΦΕΚ 175/1914] The crossed marshal's batons refer to [[Constantine I of Greece|King Constantine I]], who was raised to the rank in 1913. The flag was made redundant after the abolition of the monarchy in 1924. Following the restoration of the monarchy in 1935, the 1914 decrees regarding Greek flags and those of the royal family were reinstated by decree of 7 November 1935. This flag was replaced in 1936 with a new design.[http://www.et.gr/idocs-nph/search/pdfViewerForm.html?args=5C7QrtC22wFO_KkoXZFLcndtvSoClrL8c6_D4wm7uet5MXD0LzQTLWPU9yLzB8V68knBzLCmTXKaO6fpVZ6Lx9hLslJUqeiQDXcWtx2XOBuUCmKPaHy46nmatzZ4drAC3R56ovwa0E8. ΦΕΚ 541/1935, dated 12.11.1935, page 2656] || Like the Navy jack, but in a light blue field with the Arms of King [[Constantine I of Greece|Constantine I]] at the center. Behind the arms are two crossed [[Field Marshal]]'s batons. |- | [[File:Standard of the Crown Prince of Greece (1914 pattern).svg|140px|border]]|| 1914–1924
1935–1936 || Standard used by the Crown Prince, adopted in 1914. The flag was made redundant after the abolition of the monarchy in 1924. Following the restoration of the monarchy in 1935, the 1914 decrees regarding Greek flags and those of the royal family were reinstated by decree of 7 November 1935. This flag was replaced in 1936 with a new design.|| Like the Navy jack, but in a light blue field. In the first and third quarter is a royal crown. |- | [[File:Standard of Queen Sophia of Greece.svg|140px|border]]|| 1914–1924
1935–1936 || Standard of the Queen of Greece (in this case, showing the arms of [[Sophia of Prussia]]), adopted in 1914. The flag was made redundant after the abolition of the monarchy in 1924. Following the restoration of the monarchy in 1935, the 1914 decrees regarding Greek flags and those of the royal family were reinstated by decree of 7 November 1935. || |- | [[File:Standard of members of the Greek Royal Family (1914 pattern).svg|140px|border]]|| 1914–1924
1935–1936 || Standard used by the other members of the royal family, adopted in 1914. The flag was made redundant after the abolition of the monarchy in 1924. Following the restoration of the monarchy in 1935, the 1914 decrees regarding Greek flags and those of the royal family were reinstated by decree of 7 November 1935. || |- | [[File:Flag of Minister of Navy of Greece (1914-1924).svg|140px|border]] || 1914–1924 || The flag of the Minister of the Navy, adopted in 1914.[http://www.et.gr/idocs-nph/search/pdfViewerForm.html?args=5C7QrtC22wEpPcAGqWYddHdtvSoClrL8r_t-tPq24FR5MXD0LzQTLWPU9yLzB8V68knBzLCmTXKaO6fpVZ6Lx3UnKl3nP8NxdnJ5r9cmWyJWelDvWS_18kAEhATUkJb0x1LIdQ163nV9K--td6SIufxyD1yiVq2Y-uUQ1UR3EOYxVVeeioiYBuL_IKxURr0- Royal Decree of 31 May 1914, published in ΦΕΚ 175/1914] || |- | [[File:Royal Standard of the Kingdom of Greece (1936-1967).svg|140px|border]] || 1936–1974 || Royal Standard of the King, adopted in 1936.per [http://www.et.gr/idocs-nph/search/pdfViewerForm.html?args=5C7QrtC22wE1WF5u8f_rVXdtvSoClrL8fnjEuKFUxZh5MXD0LzQTLWPU9yLzB8V68knBzLCmTXKaO6fpVZ6Lx9hLslJUqeiQu5S_EJjSr73TSlIn1kHeszpzSWZDqXRerJk_dIxwf14. Royal Decree of 20 February 1936, Gazette 109, dated 26.02.1936, pages 549-550]|| Like the Navy jack, with the [[Greek Royal Family|Royal Family]] arms in the centre and four crowns in the quarters. |- | [[File:Standard of the Crown Prince of Greece (1936-1967).svg|140px|border]] || 1936–1974 || Standard of the Crown Prince, adopted in 1936.|| Like the Navy jack, with the [[Greek Royal Family]] arms in the centre and one crown in the first quarter. |- | [[File:Standard of members of the Greek Royal Family (1936-1967).svg|140px|border]]|| 1936–1974 || Standard used by the [[Greek Royal Family]], adopted in 1936.|| Like the Navy jack, with the [[Greek Royal Family]] arms in the centre but no crown. |- | [[File:Hellenic Royal Flag 1935.svg|140px|Royal Flag during the Greek Royal Family]] || 1936–1970 || Royal version of the State Flag during the [[Kingdom of Greece]]. || The flag consists of the plain cross version of the national flag, with a detailed golden royal crown superimposed in the center of the cross. The field is bordered by a gold fringe. |- | [[File:Hellenic Kingdom Flag 1935.svg|140px|State and War flag on land during the Greek Royal Family|border]] || 1863–1924
1935–1970 || [[State flag|State]] and [[War flag]] on land during the [[Greek Royal Family]] in the [[Kingdom of Greece]].|| The flag consists of the plain cross version of the national flag, with a golden royal crown superimposed in the center of the cross. |- | [[File:Naval Jack of Kingdom of Greece.svg|140px|border]] || 1863–1924
1935–1970 || Jack of the [[Royal Hellenic Navy]]. || A square flag with a white cross on a blue field with the Hellenic Royal Crown in the centre. The crown was added during the periods of monarchy (1833–1924 and 1935–1973). |- | [[File:Hellenic Naval Ensign 1935.svg|140px|State flag and War ensign for naval vessels during the Greek Royal Family|border]] || 1863–1924
1935–1970 || [[State flag|State]] and [[War ensign]] at sea during the [[Greek Royal Family]] in the [[Kingdom of Greece]].|| The flag consists of the naval version of the national flag, with a golden royal crown superimposed in the center of the cross in the canton. |- | [[File:Ensign of the Royal Hellenic Air Force.svg|140px|border]] || || Ensign of the Royal Hellenic Air Force until 1973. || A white cross on a blue field with the roundel of the Hellenic Air Force in the centre, the royal crown in a circle on the canton. |- | [[File:Flag of the Hellenic Air Force (1973-1978).svg|140px|border]] || || Ensign of the [[Hellenic Air Force]] (1973–1978) and Greek [[Civil air ensign|Civil Air Ensign]], until 1978. || A white cross on a blue field with the roundel of the Hellenic Air Force in the centre. |- | [[File:Hellenic Coast Guard Flag.svg|140px|border]] || 1964–1980 || [[Hellenic Coast Guard]] service flag.|| The naval ensign with two golden anchors, crossed, in the centre of the cross. |- | [[File:Flag of Greece (1970-1975).svg|140px|National flag on land during the Colonels' Regime|border]] || 1970–1975 || National flag adopted by the [[Greek military junta of 1967-1974|Colonels' regime]]. || The sea flag, in ratio 7:12 and in very dark shade of blue (dark "[[midnight blue]]"). The old "land" version was restored as national flag in 1975. |- |} ==Current and historical variants used outside Greece== {| border="2" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 1em 1em 1em 0; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse;" |- bgcolor="#efefef" ! width="110"|Flag!!width="80"|Date!!width="300"|Use!!width="300"|Description |- | [[File:Flag of the Principality of Samos (1834–1912).svg|140px|Flag of the Principality of Samos|border]] || 1834–1912 || Flag of the autonomous [[Principality of Samos]], tributary to the [[Ottoman Empire]]. || The flag consists of the plain cross version of the Greek national flag, with the upper half field in the red of the [[Ottoman flag]]. |- | [[File:Flag of Cretan State.svg|140px|Flag of the Cretan State|border]] || 1898–1908 || Flag of the autonomous [[Cretan State]]. || The flag consists of the plain cross version of the Greek national flag, with the canton in red with a white five-pointed star, symbolizing Ottoman suzerainty. It was not popular during its period of official use, as Cretans wanted union with Greece, and was ''de facto'' abolished following the island's unilateral proclamation of union with Greece in September 1908. |- |[[File:Arkadi Cretan flag.svg|140px|Flag used during the siege of Arkadi|border]] || 1866 || Flag used in the [[Arkadi Monastery]] by Christian Cretans supporting union with Greece, during the [[Cretan Revolt (1866–1869)|Great Cretan Revolt of 1866–1869]]. || The flag consists of the plain cross version of the Greek national flag, featuring the initials of the motto '''Κ'''ρήτη, '''Έ'''νωσις, '''Ε'''λευθερία '''ή''' '''Θ'''άνατος ("Crete, [[Enosis]], Freedom or Death"), and the cross with the inscription ΙΣ ΧΣ ΝΙΚΑ ("Jesus Christ Conquers"). |- | [[File:Flag of the Free State of Ikaria.svg|140px|border]] || 1912 || Flag of the Free State of [[Ikaria]]. || |- | [[File:Flag of Northern Epirus.PNG|140px|border]] || 1914 || Flag of the [[Autonomous Republic of Northern Epirus]]. ||It is used until today by many Northern Epirots. |- | [[File:Tr ponto2.gif|140px|border]] || 1917–1922 || Flag of the [[Republic of Pontus]]. ||Used until today by many Pontic Greeks. |- | [[File:Flag of EOKA.tif|140px|Flag of EOKA|border]] || 1955–1959 || Flag of [[EOKA|Ethniki Organosis Kyprion Agoniston]] (National Organisation of Cypriot Fighters), Greek Cypriot organisation that fought for the end of British rule in Cyprus, for the island's self-determination and for eventual union with Greece. || The flag consist a white cross on a blue field with Cyprus in the middle. It is used until today in Cyprus by many [[Greek Cypriots]]. |- | [[File:Naval Jack of Cyprus.png|140px|border]] || since 1964 || Jack of the [[Cyprus Navy]]. || A square flag with a white cross on a blue field, with a crossed anchor, trident and cross in gold superimposed. |} ==Historical Greek flags== {| border="2" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 1em 1em 1em 0; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse;" |- bgcolor="#efefef" ! width="110"|Flag!!width="80"|Date!!width="300"|Use!!width="300"|Description |- ||| c. 1350 || Flag of Constantinople, attested in the 14th-century Spanish atlas ''[[Libro del Conoscimiento|Conosçimiento de todos los reynos]]'' || The flag features the red [[St. George's cross]] (possibly associated with the [[Republic of Genoa|Genoese]] colony of [[Galata]]) and the dynastic arms of the [[Palaiologos|Palaeologi]], the tetragrammatic cross with the four betas (commonly, as here, depicted in the form of stylized fire-steles). |- |[[File:Byzantine imperial flag, 14th century.svg|140px|Tetragrammatic cross flag]] || || Also in Spanish atlas ''Conoscimento de todos los reinos'' the well-documented "plain" tetragrammatic cross (a symbol of the Palaiologos dynasty) flag [http://www.crwflags.com/fotw/flags/gr_byz.html#con is presented] as the flag "of the real Greece and Empire of the Greeks (la vera Grecia e el imperio de los griegos)" (not being clear whether this implies usage of the quartered flag only in Constantinople). || Golden cross with four betas on red field. |- | [[File:Spachides Flag.svg|140px|border|Flag of the Greek ''spachides'']] || 1431–1619 || The Greek [[sipahi]] cavalry units serving with the Turkish army were allowed to use this flag during the first centuries of [[Ottoman Greece|Ottoman rule]], when within the territory of [[Epirus]] and the [[Peloponnese]]. Similar flags were used during the [[Greek Revolution]]. || A blue cross over a white field, with an image of [[St. George]] slaying the dragon in the middle. |- | [[File:Flag of Ottoman Greece.svg|140px|The "Graeco-Ottoman" naval ensign]] || || This flag, the so-called "Graeco-Ottoman" ensign (Γραικοθωμανική παντιέρα), was allowed for use by Greek merchant ships during the latter stages of Ottoman rule. || The flag consists of three horizontal stripes in the colours red (for the [[Ottoman Empire]]), blue (for the Greeks) and red (''see [[Ottoman Flag#Flags of the Sublime Porte (1453-1789)|article on Ottoman flags]]''). |- | [[File:Filiki Eteria flag.svg|140px|border|Flag of Filiki Eteria]] || || The flag of the [[Filiki Eteria]]. || |- | [[File:Areios Pagos Anatolikis Ellados.svg|140px|]] || 1821–1825 || The flag of the [[Areopagus of Eastern Continental Greece]], a regional administration during the [[Greek Revolution]]. || The flag consists of three vertical stripes in the colours green, white and black. The cross stands for Orthodox Christianity, the flaming heart for the will to fight for independence, and the anchor for the steadfastness of purpose. |- | [[File:YpsilantisFlag.svg|140px|border|Flag of the Sacred Band]] || 1821 || Flag of the [[Sacred Band (1821)|Sacred Band]]. || |- | [[File:Athanasios Diakos 1821.svg|140px|border|Flag of Athanasios Diakos]] || 1821 || Used by [[Athanasios Diakos]] and his irregulars during the [[Greek War of Independence]]. || The figure of St. George slaying the dragon, with the motto Ελευθερία ή θάνατος (''Freedom or Death''). |- | [[File:Andreas Lontos Flag (Revolution1821).svg|140px|Flag of Andreas Londos]] || 1821 || The first Greek revolutionary flag, raised at the beginning of the [[Greek War of Independence]] by [[Andreas Londos]].|| A black Latin cross in the center of a red field. |- | [[File:Alexander Ypsilantis flag (obverse).svg|140px|border|Flag of Alexander Ypsilantis]] || 1821 || Used by [[Alexander Ypsilantis (1792–1828)|Alexander Ypsilantis]]. || |- | [[File:1821 Flag of Gazis.svg|140px|border|Flag of Anthimos Gazis]] || 1821 || Used by [[Anthimos Gazis]] and his irregulars from [[Thessaly]] during the [[Greek War of Independence]]. |- | [[File:Thessalia-flag.jpg|140px|]] || 1821|| Another flag used also in [[Thessaly]] during the War of Independence, created also by Anthimos Gazis. |- | [[File:Flag of the Administration of Samos.svg|140px|border|Flag of Samos]] || 1821 || Flag of the [[Military-Political System of Samos]] during the [[Greek War of Independence]]. || |- | [[File:Halkidiki flag (1821).svg|140px|border|Flag of Chalkidiki]] || 1821 || Flag of the revolutionaries from Chalkidiki during the [[Greek War of Independence]]. || |- | [[File: Greek flag (black cross).svg|140px|border|Flag of Thrace]] || 1821 || Flag of the revolutionaries from Thrace and [[Samothrace]] during the [[Greek War of Independence]]. || |- | [[File:Mani Flag (Greece).svg|140px|border|Flag of the [[Maniots]].]] || 1821 || The flag of the fighters of the autonomous [[Mani Peninsula]]. || A blue [[Greek cross]] on white background, with the words "Victory or Death" and the ancient [[Sparta]]n motto "[[List of Greek phrases#Ηη|With it or upon it]]" in gold. |- | [[File:Flag of the Septinsular Republic.svg|140px|Flag of the Septinsular Republic]] || 1800–1807 || Flag of the [[Septinsular Republic]], the first modern Greek self-governing state, comprising the [[Ionian Islands]], under joint [[Russian Empire|Russian]] and [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] suzerainty. || The flag depicts the "[[Lion of St. Mark]]", the symbol of the [[Republic of Venice]], under whose [[Venetian Ionian Islands|rule]] the Ionian Islands were until 1797. The lion holds seven bundled arrows, representing the unity of the seven islands, with the [[Bible]] superimposed on them. |- | [[File:Flag of the United States of the Ionian Islands.svg|140px|Flag of the Ionian Islands under British rule|border]] || 1817–1864 || Flag of the [[United States of the Ionian Islands]], a [[United Kingdom|British]] protectorate from 1815 until its unity with [[Greece]] in 1864. || The flag is a variation of the British colonial [[Blue Ensign]], with red bordering. It is [[defacement (flag)|defaced]] with the islands' emblem, a variant of the [[Venice|Venetian]] "[[Lion of St. Mark]]" holding seven bundled arrows, representing the unity of the seven [[Ionian Islands]], with the [[Bible]] superimposed on them. |- | [[File:Princely Flag of the Principality of Samos (1834–1912).svg|140px|Flag of the Principality of Samos|border]] || 1834–1912 || Princely flag of the autonomous [[Principality of Samos]], tributary to the [[Ottoman Empire]]. || The flag consists of a white triangle on blue background, bearing a red [[Greek cross]] in the centre. |- |} ==See also== * [[Flag of Greece]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Flags of Greece}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080501124001/http://www.coconis.gr/historical.html Kokkonis Flag Factory - Historical Flags]. * [http://www.crwflags.com/fotw/flags/gr.html FotW: Greece] * [https://www.academia.edu/32481895/Origin_and_Evolution_of_the_Greek_Flag Origin and Evolution of the Greek Flag, March 2017 (Open Access eBook)] {{Lists of flags}} {{Greece topics}} {{DEFAULTSORT:List Of Greek Flags}} [[Category:Lists and galleries of flags|Greece]] [[Category:Flags of Greece| ]] [[Category:Greece-related lists|Flags]]

revision.text:
[[File:Map of USA NC.svg|thumb|Location of the [[state of North Carolina]] in the [[United States|United States of America]]]] The [[state of North Carolina]] has 42 official state emblems, as well as other designated places and events. The majority are determined by acts of the [[North Carolina General Assembly]] and record in Chapters 144, 145, and 149 of the North Carolina General Statutes.{{cite web|title=Chapter 145 - State Symbols and Other Official Adoptions|url=http://www.ncleg.net/EnactedLegislation/Statutes/HTML/ByChapter/Chapter_145.html|publisher=North Carolina General Assembly|accessdate=14 August 2014}} The state's nicknames – "The Old North State" and "The Tar Heel State" – are both traditional, but have never been passed into law by the General Assembly. The first symbol was the [[Seal of North Carolina]], which was made official in 1871. The original seal also contained the future state motto. It served as the state's only emblem for 14 years until the adoption of the [[Flag of North Carolina|state flag]] in 1885. Enacted by law in 2013, the newest symbols of North Carolina are the state art medium, [[clay]]; the state fossil, the [[Megalodon#Teeth|Megalodon teeth]]; the state frog, the [[Pine Barrens tree frog]]; the state marsupial, the [[Virginia opossum]]; and the state salamander, the [[Marbled salamander]]. ==Insignia== {| class="wikitable" |- ! align="center"| Type ! align="center"| Symbol ! align="center"| Year ! align="center"| Image ! align="center"| Source |- |'''[[State flag|Flag]]''' |"That the [[flag of North Carolina]] shall consist of a blue union, containing in the center thereof a white star with the letter N in gilt on the left and the letter C in gilt on the right of said star, the circle containing the same to be one-third the width of the union. The fly of the flag shall consist of two equally proportioned bars; the upper bar to be red, the lower bar to be white; that the length of the bars horizontally shall be equal to the perpendicular length of the union, and the total length of the flag shall be one-third more than its width. That above the star in the center of the union there shall be a gilt scroll in semi-circular form, containing in black letters this inscription 'May 20, 1775,' and that below the star there shall be a similar scroll containing in black letters the inscription: 'April 12, 1776.'" |align="center"|1885 |align="center"|[[File:Flag of North Carolina.svg|100px|North Carolina flag]] |align="center"|{{cite web|title=State flag|url=http://www.ncleg.net/EnactedLegislation/Statutes/HTML/BySection/Chapter_144/GS_144-1.html|publisher=North Carolina General Assembly|accessdate=13 August 2014}} |- ||'''[[List of U.S. state mottos|Motto]]''' |''[[Esse quam videri]]''
("To be, rather than to seem") |align="center"|1893 |align="center"|— |align="center"|{{cite web|title=State motto|url=http://www.ncleg.net/EnactedLegislation/Statutes/HTML/BySection/Chapter_144/GS_144-2.html|publisher=North Carolina General Assembly|accessdate=13 August 2014}} |- |'''[[List of U.S. state nicknames|Nicknames]]''' |'''Old North State'''
'''[[Tar Heel]] State''' |align="center"|Traditional |align="center"|— |align="center"|{{cite web|title=North Carolina State Symbols|url=http://www.secretary.state.nc.us/kidspg/symbols.htm|publisher=North Carolina Secretary of State|accessdate=13 August 2014}} |- |'''[[Seals of the U.S. states|Seal]]''' |The [[Seal of North Carolina]] |align="center"|1871 (Revised in 1983) |align="center"|[[File:NorthCarolina-StateSeal.svg|100px|North Carolina state seal]] |align="center"| |} ==Flora== {| class="wikitable" |- ! align="center"| Type ! align="center"| Symbol ! align="center" | Year ! align="center"| Image ! align="center"| Source |- |'''Carnivorous plant''' |[[Venus Flytrap]]
''Dionaea muscipula'' |align="center"|2005 |align="center"|[[File:Flytrap.jpg|100px|Venus flytrap]] |align="center"|{{cite web|title=State carnivorous plant|url=http://www.ncleg.net/EnactedLegislation/Statutes/HTML/BySection/Chapter_145/GS_145-22.html|publisher=North Carolina General Assembly|accessdate=13 August 2014}} |- |'''[[List of U.S. state trees|Christmas tree]]''' |[[Fraser Fir]]
''Abies fraseri'' |align="center"|2005 |align="center"|[[File:Abies fraseri cone.jpg|100px|Fraser Fir]] |align="center"|{{cite web|title=State Christmas tree|url=http://www.ncleg.net/EnactedLegislation/Statutes/HTML/BySection/Chapter_145/GS_145-25.html|publisher=North Carolina General Assembly|accessdate=13 August 2014}} |- |'''[[List of U.S. state flowers|Flower]]''' |[[Flowering Dogwood]]
''Cornus florida'' |align="center"|1941 |align="center"|[[File:Benthamidia florida2.jpg|100px|American Dogwood]] |align="center"|{{cite web|title=State flower|url=http://www.ncleg.net/EnactedLegislation/Statutes/HTML/BySection/Chapter_145/GS_145-1.html|publisher=North Carolina General Assembly|accessdate=13 August 2014}} |- |'''[[List of U.S. state trees|Tree]]''' |[[Pine]]
''Genus Pinus'' |align="center"|1963 |align="center"|[[File:Longleaf 8246.jpg|100px|Pine]] |align="center"|{{cite web|title=State tree|url=http://www.ncleg.net/EnactedLegislation/Statutes/HTML/BySection/Chapter_145/GS_145-3.html|publisher=North Carolina General Assembly|accessdate=13 August 2014}} |- |'''[[List of U.S. state flowers|Wildflower]]''' |[[Lilium michauxii|Carolina Lily]]
''Lilium michauxii'' |align="center"|2003 |align="center"| |align="center"|{{cite web|title=State wildflower|url=http://www.ncleg.net/EnactedLegislation/Statutes/HTML/BySection/Chapter_145/GS_145-20.html|publisher=North Carolina General Assembly|accessdate=13 August 2014}} |} ==Fauna== {| class="wikitable" |- ! align="center" | Type ! align="center" | Symbol ! align="center" | Year ! align="center" | Image ! align="center" | Source |- |'''[[List of U.S. state birds|Bird]]''' |[[Cardinal (bird)|Cardinal]] |align="center"|1943 |align="center"|[[File:Northern Cardinal Female-27527.jpg|100px]] |align="center"|{{cite web|title=State bird|url=http://www.ncleg.net/EnactedLegislation/Statutes/HTML/BySection/Chapter_145/GS_145-2.html|publisher=North Carolina General Assembly|accessdate=13 August 2014}} |- |'''[[List of U.S. state butterflies|Butterfly]]''' |[[Papilio glaucus|Eastern tiger swallowtail]] |align="center"|2012 |align="center"|[[File:Eastern Tiger Swallowtail Papilio glaucus Wings 2908px.jpg|100px|Eastern tiger swallowtail]] |align="center"|{{cite web|title=State butterfly|url=http://www.ncleg.net/EnactedLegislation/Statutes/HTML/BySection/Chapter_145/GS_145-38.html|publisher=North Carolina General Assembly|accessdate=13 August 2014}} |- |'''[[List of U.S. state mammals|Dog]]''' |[[Plott Hound]] |align="center"|1989 |align="center"|[[File:Plotthound.jpg|100px|Plott Hound]] |align="center"|{{cite web|title=State dog|url=http://www.ncleg.net/EnactedLegislation/Statutes/HTML/BySection/Chapter_145/GS_145-13.html|publisher=North Carolina General Assembly|accessdate=13 August 2014}} |- |'''[[List of U.S. state fossils|Fossil]]''' |[[Megalodon#Teeth|Megalodon teeth]] |align="center"|2013 |align="center"|[[File:Carcharodon megalodon (Agassiz, 1837) - 13,5 cm.jpg|thumb|119x119px]] |align="center"|{{cite web|title=State fossil|url=http://www.ncleg.net/EnactedLegislation/Statutes/HTML/BySection/Chapter_145/GS_145-41.html|publisher=North Carolina General Assembly|accessdate=13 August 2014}} |- |'''[[List of U.S. state fish|Freshwater trout]]''' |[[Brook trout|Southern Appalachian brook trout]] |align="center"|2005 |align="center"|[[File:Brook Trout Salvelinus fontinalis 2900px.jpg|100px|brook trout]] |align="center"|{{cite web|title=State freshwater trout|url=http://www.ncleg.net/EnactedLegislation/Statutes/HTML/BySection/Chapter_145/GS_145-26.html|publisher=North Carolina General Assembly|accessdate=13 August 2014}} |- |'''[[List of U.S. state amphibians|Frog]]''' |[[Pine Barrens tree frog]]

revision.comment: What do you mean "Critically not endangered" ?? (fixed broken link)
revision.text:
{{Birds by population sidebar}} This is a '''list of bird species by global population''', divided by [[bird classification]]. While numbers are estimates, they have been made by the experts in their fields. For more information on how these estimates were ascertained, see Wikipedia's articles on [[population biology]] and [[population ecology]]. Contributing organizations include the [[IUCN]], [[BirdLife International]], and [[Partners in Flight]].
This list is incomplete, because experts have not estimated all bird numbers. For example, the [[spectacled flowerpecker]] was only discovered in 2010, and has yet to be classified with a [[Linnean name]], but would add to the other 73 new bird species described by [[ornithologist]]s from 2000 – 2009.<ref name=SA>Reuters. [http://www.scientificamerican.com/article.cfm?id=spectacled-flowerpecker-b ''"Spectacled flowerpecker" bird found in Borneo''], scientificamerican.com, 13 January 2010, accessed on 15 January 2010.</ref><ref name=BBC>Walton, Doreen, science reporter. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/8457642.stm ''New bird species found in rainforests of Borneo''], BBC News, news.bbc.co.uk, 14 January 2010, accessed on 15 January 2010.</ref><ref name='decade'>{{cite web | url = http://timgostony.com/iisetemp/RetroSOS__FINAL.pdf | title = State of observed species: A decade of species discovery in review | accessdate = 2013-01-02 | last = Pennak | first = Sara | date = 18 January 2012 | format = PDF | publisher = Arizona State University: International Institute for Species Exploration | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20121031181854/http%3A//timgostony.com/iisetemp/RetroSOS__FINAL.pdf | archivedate = 31 October 2012 | df = }}</ref> Global population estimates for many of these at this time would lack accuracy.
All numbers are estimates, because they are taken by [[observation]], and a given number of 50 [[slender-billed curlew]]s does not necessarily mean there are 10 more of this species than the [[black stilt]], which has been estimated at 40: there is a possibility that the latter species has a larger population than the former.<ref name='Himantopus novaezelandiae IUCN'>{{cite web | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/106003103/0 | title = Himantopus novaezelandiae | accessdate = 2012-12-06 | author = [[BirdLife International]] | year = 2012 | work = [[IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]]. Version 2012.2 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121112061507/http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/106003103/0 | archivedate = 2012-11-12 | df = }}</ref><ref name='Numenius tenuirostris IUCN'>{{cite web | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/106003011/0 | title = Numenius tenuirostris | accessdate = 2012-12-06 | author = [[BirdLife International]] | year = 2012 | work = [[IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]]. Version 2012.2 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121112050611/http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/106003011/0 | archivedate = 2012-11-12 | df = }}</ref> This list should not be taken that literally. An estimate of 250 [[shore dotterel]]s compared with 4,500 – 5,000 [[wrybill]]s, on the other hand, means that the latter has well over one [[order of magnitude]] more individuals than the former.<ref name='Thinornis novaeseelandiae IUCN'>{{cite web | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/106003145/0 | title = Thinornis novaeseelandiae | accessdate = 2012-12-09 | author = [[BirdLife International]] | year = 2012 | work = [[IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]]. Version 2012.2 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130927081738/http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/106003145/0 | archivedate = 2013-09-27 | df = }}</ref><ref name='Anarhynchus frontalis IUCN'>{{cite web | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/106003149/0 | title = Anarhynchus frontalis | accessdate = 2012-12-05 | author = [[BirdLife International]] | year = 2012 | work = [[IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]]. Version 2012.2 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130927043219/http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/106003149/0 | archivedate = 2013-09-27 | df = }}</ref> The wrybill only has approximately one tenth the population of [[great skua]]s (48,000), which are outnumbered ~10:1 by the [[pigeon guillemot]] (470,000).<ref name='Stercorarius skua IUCN'>{{cite web | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/106003195/0 | title = Stercorarius skua | accessdate = 2012-12-09 | author = [[BirdLife International]] | year = 2012 | work = [[IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]]. Version 2012.2 | publisher = [[IUCN]] }}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref name='Cepphus columba IUCN'>{{cite web | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/106003307/0 | title = Cepphus columba | accessdate = 2012-12-05 | author = [[BirdLife International]] | year = 2012 | work = [[IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]]. Version 2012.2 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131021044549/http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/106003307/0 | archivedate = 2013-10-21 | df = }}</ref> It is these large differences between species that this list tries to convey. ==By taxonomy== {| class="wikitable" |- ! width="15%"|'''List by taxonomic order''' ! width="15%"|Birds included ! width="15%"| # of quantified species / # of total species (%){{ref|a|1}} ! colspan="2"|Example of less common species ! colspan="2"|Example of more common species |- | rowspan="2" style="border-bottom: 3px solid grey;"|'''[[List of Anseriformes by population|Anseriformes]]''' ||rowspan="2" style="border-bottom: 3px solid grey;"|Waterfowl: ducks, geese, swans. || rowspan="2" align=center style="border-bottom: 3px solid grey;"|89 / 166 (54%)||align=center style="background:#F08080"| [[Laysan duck]] ([[Critically endangered species|CR]]) || rowspan="2" align=center style="border-bottom: 3px solid grey;"|[[Image:Laysan teal male.jpg|100px]] ||align=center style="background:#B0E0E6"| [[Mallard]] ([[Least concern|LC]]) || rowspan="2" align=center style="border-bottom: 3px solid grey;"| [[Image:Mallard in flight.jpg|100px]] |- |align=center style="border-bottom: 3px solid grey;"|Pop: '''521'''<ref name='Anas laysanensis IUCN'>{{cite web | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/100600437/0 | title = Anas laysanensis | accessdate = 2012-11-28 | author = [[BirdLife International]] | year = 2012 | work = [[IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]]. Version 2012.2 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121111094827/http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/100600437/0 | archivedate = 2012-11-11 | df = }}</ref> ||align=center style="border-bottom: 3px solid grey;"|Pop: '''> 17,000,000'''<ref name='Anas platyrhynchos IUCN'>{{cite web | url = http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/100600435/0 | title = Anas platyrhynchos | accessdate = 2012-11-28 | author = [[BirdLife International]] | year = 2012 | work = [[IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]]. Version 2012.2 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121112021225/http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/100600435/0 | archivedate = 2012-11-12 | df = }}</ref> |- | rowspan="2" style="border-bottom: 3px solid grey;"|'''[[List of Apodiformes by population|Apodiformes]]''' ||rowspan="2" style="border-bottom: 3px solid grey;"|Swifts, hummingbirds. || rowspan="2" align=center style="border-bottom: 3px solid grey;"|86 / 441 (20%)||align=center style="background:#F08080"| [[Juan Fernández firecrown]] ([[Critically endangered species|CR]]) || rowspan="2" align=center style="border-bottom: 3px solid grey;"|[[Image:Sephanoides fernandensis.jpg|100px]] ||align=center style="background:#CEF2E0"| [[Chimney swift]] ([[Near threatened|NT]]) || rowspan="2" align=center style="border-bottom: 3px solid grey;"| [[Image:Chimney swift overhead.jpg|100px]] |- |align=center style="border-bottom: 3px solid grey;"|Pop: '''2,500 – 3,000'''<ref name='Sephanoides fernandensis IUCN'>{{cite web|url=http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/106002021/0 |title=Sephanoides fernandensis |accessdate=2012-12-02 |author=[[BirdLife International]] |year=2012 |work=[[IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]]. Version 2012.2 |publisher=[[IUCN]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121014071421/http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/106002021/0 |archivedate=2012-10-14 |df= }}</ref> ||align=center style="border-bottom: 3px solid grey;"|Pop: '''15,000,000'''<ref name='Chaetura pelagica IUCN'>{{cite web|url=http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/106001758/0 |title=Chaetura pelagica |accessdate=2012-12-01 |author=[[BirdLife International]] |year=2012 |work=[[IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]]. Version 2012.2 | publisher = [[IUCN]] | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130928081317/http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/106001015/0 | archivedate = 2013-09-28 | df = }}</ref> |- |}

==Notes== :1.{{note|a}}Amount of quantified species contained in the list as of the "Retrieved" date in the corresponding citation. The amount of species in each order is according to the IUCN and BirdLife International; bird taxonomy is currently in flux and these figures may soon change. :2.{{note|b}}Preliminary estimate. :3.{{note|c}}Mature only.

revision.comment: "not student societies or those otherwise restricted to a particular university or institution"
revision.text:
{{see also|List of chemistry societies}} {{chemical engineering}} This is the '''list of chemical engineering societies''' in the world. They are sorted by continent and alphabetically. They include national or international ones, but not student societies or those otherwise restricted to a particular university or institution.
==Africa== * [[Nigerian Society of Chemical Engineers]] * [http://www.saiche.co.za/ South African Institution of Chemical Engineers] (SAIChE), South Africa * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100902011443/http://www.esche.org.et/index.htm Ethiopian Society of Chemical Engineers] (ESChE), Ethiopia
==Asia== * [http://www.apcche.org/ Asia Pacific Confederation of Chemical Engineering (APCChE)] * [[Iranian Association of Chemical Engineering]] (IAChE) [http://www.che.ir], I.R. Iran * [[Indian Institute of Chemical Engineers]] (IIChe), India [http://www.iiche.org.in] * [[Israel Institute of Chemical Engineers]] (IIChe), Israel [http://www.iiche.org.il] * [[Korean Institute of Chemical Engineers]] (KIChE), Korea [http://www.kiche.or.kr/english/] * [[Philippine Institute of Chemical Engineers]] (PIChE), Philippines [http://www.pichenet.org/] * [[Society of Chemical Engineers, Japan]] (SCEJ), Japan [http://www.scej.org] * [[Society of Chemical Engineers of Nepal]], Kathmandu, Nepal [https://www.facebook.com/Society-of-Chemical-Engineers-of-Nepal-714364511990899/] * [[Taiwan Institute of Chemical Engineering]] (TwIChE), Taiwan [http://www.twiche.org.tw] * [[Thai Institute of Chemical Engineering and Applied Chemistry]] (TIChE), Thailand [http://www.tiche.org]
==Europe== * [[European Federation of Chemical Engineering]] (EFCE) (umbrella organization) * [http://www.aidic.it/ Associazione Italiana Di Ingegneria Chimica] (AIDIC), Italy * [[DECHEMA]], Germany * [[Institution of Chemical Engineers]] (IChemE), UK * [[Société Française de Génie des Procédés]] (SFGP), France
==North America== * [[American Chemical Society]] (ACS) * [[American Institute of Chemical Engineers]] (AIChE) * [[Association of Energy Engineers]] (AEE) * [[Canadian Society for Chemical Engineering]] (CSChE) * [[National Organization for the Professional Advancement of Black Chemists and Chemical Engineers]] (NOBCChE) * [https://web.archive.org/web/20081219183516/http://www.imiq.org/ Mexican Institute of Chemical Engineers] (IMIQ), Mexico
==Oceania== * [http://www.anzfche.org/ The Australian and New Zealand Federation of Chemical Engineers (ANZFChE)] * [[Engineers Australia]] [https://www.engineersaustralia.org.au/Communities-And-Groups/Colleges/Chemical Chemical College], Australia * [https://web.archive.org/web/20081014025850/http://www.scenz.org.nz/cenz.htm Society of Chemical Engineers New Zealand]
==South America== * [http://www.aaiq.org.ar/ Argentinian Association for Chemical Engineers], Argentina * [http://www.abeq.org.br/ Brazilian Association of Chemical Engineering], Brazil * [http://aciq.co/ Colombian Association of Chemical Engineering], Colombia * [http://www.aiqu.org.uy/ Association of Chemical Engineers of Uruguay], Uruguay
==References== <references /> {{Chemical engg}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:List Of Chemical Engineering Societies}} [[Category:Lists of organizations|Chemical engineering]] [[Category:Chemical engineering organizations]] [[Category:Chemistry societies| Chemical engineering]] [[Category:Chemistry-related lists|Societies, chemical engineering]]

page.title: List of protein structure prediction software

revision.comment: /* Secondary structure prediction */
revision.text:
{{external links|date=November 2014}} This '''list of protein structure prediction software''' summarizes commonly used software tools in [[protein structure prediction]], including [[homology modeling]], [[protein threading]], ''ab initio'' methods, [[Protein structure prediction#Secondary structure|secondary structure prediction]], and transmembrane helix and signal peptide prediction. ==Software list== {{main|Protein structure prediction}} Below is a list which separates programs according to the method used for structure prediction. ===Homology modeling=== {{main|Homology modeling}} {| class="sortable wikitable" style="text-align: center" |- ! Name ! Method || Description || Link |- | IntFOLD |A unified interface for: Tertiary structure prediction/3D modelling, 3D model quality assessment, Intrinsic disorder prediction, Domain prediction, Prediction of protein-ligand binding residues || Automated webserver and some downloadable programs || [http://www.reading.ac.uk/bioinf/IntFOLD/ server and downloads] |- |- | [[RaptorX]] |remote homology detection, protein 3D modeling, binding site prediction || Automated webserver and Downloadable program || [http://raptorx.uchicago.edu/ server and download] |- | [[Biskit]] | wraps external programs into automated workflow || [[BLAST]] search, [[T-Coffee]] alignment, and [[MODELLER]] construction || [http://biskit.sf.net/ project site] |- | CABS | Reduced modeling tool || Downloadable program || [https://web.archive.org/web/20121009080857/http://www.biocomp.chem.uw.edu.pl/services.php download] |- | [[CPHModel]] | Fragment assembly || Automated webserver || [http://www.cbs.dtu.dk/services/CPHmodels/ server] |- |[[ESyPred3D]] | Template detection, alignment, 3D modeling || Automated webserver || [http://www.fundp.ac.be/urbm/bioinfo/esypred/ server] |- | [[FoldX]] | Energy calculations and protein design || Downloadable program || [http://foldx.crg.es/ download] |- | [[GeneSilico]] | Consensus template search/fragment assembly || Webserver || [http://www.genesilico.pl/meta/ server] |- | [[Geno3D]] | Satisfaction of spatial restraints || Automated webserver || [http://geno3d-pbil.ibcp.fr/ server] |- |[[HHpred / HHsearch|HHpred]] | Template detection, alignment, 3D modeling || Interactive webserver with help facility || [http://arquivo.pt/wayback/20160514083149/http%3A//toolkit.tuebingen.mpg.de/hhpred server] [ftp://ftp.tuebingen.mpg.de/pub/protevo/HHsearch download] [http://nar.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/reprint/33/suppl_2/W244?ijkey=FuurmQ3jgumZ6AU&keytype=ref article] |- |[[Homology Modeling Professional for HyperChem]] | Template detection, alignment, secondary structure prediction, 3D modeling, ab initio loop modeling, energy-based side-chain rotamer prediction || Standalone windows executable || [http://www.molfunction.com/software1.htm Home page] |- | [[LOMETS]] | Local Meta threading server || Meta-server combining 9 different programs || [http://zhanglab.ccmb.med.umich.edu/LOMETS/ Server] [http://zhanglab.ccmb.med.umich.edu/I-TASSER/download/ download] |- | [[MODELLER]] | Satisfaction of spatial restraints || Standalone program mainly in [[Fortran]] and [[Python (programming language)|Python]] || [http://salilab.org/modeller/ download] [http://salilab.org/modweb/ Server] |- | [[Molecular Operating Environment|MOE (Molecular Operating Environment)]] | Template identification, use of multiple templates and accounting for other environments (e.g. excluded ligand volumes), loop modelling, rotamer libraries for sidechain conformations, relaxation using MM forcefields. || Proprietary platform, supported on Windows, Linux and Mac || [http://www.chemcomp.com site] |- | [[Phyre / Phyre2|Phyre and Phyre2]] | Remote template detection, alignment, 3D modeling, multi-templates, ''ab initio'' || Webserver with job manager, automatically updated fold library, genome searching and other facilities || [http://www.sbg.bio.ic.ac.uk/~phyre/ server] |- | [[Schrödinger_(company)|Prime]] | Physics-based energy function || Graphical interface, sequence alignment, secondary structure prediction, homology modeling, protein refinement, loop-prediction, and side-chain prediction || [https://www.schrodinger.com/prime site] |- | [[Rosetta@home#Robetta|ROBETTA]] | Rosetta homology modeling and ab initio fragment assembly with Ginzu domain prediction || Webserver || [http://robetta.bakerlab.org/ server] |- | [[Supercomputing Facility for Bioinformatics and Computational Biology|BHAGEERATH-H]] | Combination of ab initio folding and homology methods || Protein tertiary structure predictions || [http://www.scfbio-iitd.res.in/bhageerath/bhageerath_h.jsp server] |- | [[Selvita Protein Modeling Platform]] | Package of tools for protein modeling || Free demo, interactive webserver and standalone program including: [[BLAST]] search, CABS modeling, 3D threading, Psi-Pred secondary structure prediction || [http://www.selvita.com/selvita-protein-modeling-platform.html Home page] |- |[[STRUCTUROPEDIA]] | WebInterface to MODELLER || Homology modeling of proteins in monomeric or multimeric forms alone and in complex with peptides and DNA as well as introduction of mutations and post-translational modifications (PTMs) into protein structures || [http://structuropedia.org/ server] |- | [[SWISS-MODEL]] | Local similarity/fragment assembly || Automated webserver (based on ProModII) || [http://swissmodel.expasy.org/ server] |- | [[TIP-STRUCTFAST]] | Automated Comparative Modeling || Webserver || [http://www.eidogen.com/structfast.php site] |- | [[WHAT IF]] | Position specific rotamers || Standalone program and webinterface|| [https://web.archive.org/web/20130618170139/http://swift.cmbi.kun.nl/whatif/ Home page] [http://swift.cmbi.ru.nl/servers/html/index.html Webinterface] |- | [[Yasara]] | Detection of templates, alignment, modeling incl. ligands and oligomers, hybridization of model fragments || Graphical interface or text mode (clusters) || [http://www.yasara.org/ Home page] [http://www.yasara.org/casp8.htm CASP8 results] |} ===Threading/fold recognition=== {{main|Protein threading}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center" |- ! Name ! Method || Description || Link |- | IntFOLD |A unified interface for: Tertiary structure prediction/3D modelling, 3D model quality assessment, Intrinsic disorder prediction, Domain prediction, Prediction of protein-ligand binding residues || Automated webserver and some downloadable programs || [http://www.reading.ac.uk/bioinf/IntFOLD/ server and downloads] |- |- |[[RaptorX / software for protein modeling and analysis|RaptorX]] | Remote template detection, single-template and multi-template threading, totally different from and much better than the old program RAPTOR designed by the same group || Webserver with job manager, automatically updated fold library || [http://raptorx.uchicago.edu/ download]
[http://raptorx.uchicago.edu/ server] |- | FALCON@home | Single-template and multi-template threading, a high-throughput server based on volunteer computing | Webserver with job manager | [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26454278 article] [http://protein.ict.ac.cn/FALCON server] |- |[[HHpred / HHsearch|HHpred]] | Template detection, alignment, 3D modeling || Interactive webserver with help facility || [https://toolkit.tuebingen.mpg.de/#/tools/hhpred server] [ftp://ftp.tuebingen.mpg.de/pub/protevo/HHsearch download] [http://bioinformatics.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/content/abstract/bti125?ijkey=38Cp1qeK4zozg&keytype=ref article] |- | [[NovaFold]] | Combination of threading and ab initio folding || Commercial protein structure prediction application || [http://www.dnastar.com/t-products-NovaFold.aspx Home page] |- | I-TASSER | Combination of ab initio folding and threading methods || Structural and function predictions || [http://zhanglab.ccmb.med.umich.edu/I-TASSER/ server] [http://zhanglab.ccmb.med.umich.edu/I-TASSER/download download] |- | mGenTHREADER/GenTHREADER | Sequence profile and predicted secondary structure || Webserver || [http://bioinf.cs.ucl.ac.uk/psipred/ main page] |- | MUSTER | profile-profile alignment || Webserver || [http://zhanglab.ccmb.med.umich.edu/MUSTER server] [http://zhanglab.ccmb.med.umich.edu/I-TASSER/download download] |- | [[Phyre / Phyre2|Phyre and Phyre2]] | Remote template detection, alignment, 3D modeling, multi-templates, ''ab initio'' || Webserver with job manager, automatically updated fold library, genome searching and other facilities || [http://www.sbg.bio.ic.ac.uk/~phyre2/ server] |- | [[Selvita Protein Modeling Platform]] | Package of tools for protein modeling || Free demo, interactive webserver and standalone program including: 3D threading and flexible 3d threading || [http://www.selvita.com/selvita-protein-modeling-platform.html Home page] |- | SUPERFAMILY | Hidden Markov modeling || Webserver/standalone || [http://supfam.org/SUPERFAMILY/ main page] |- | SPARKS-X | 3D structure modeling by Fold recognition according to Sequence profiles and structural profiles || Webserver || [http://sparks-lab.org/yueyang/server/SPARKS-X/ Server] |- | BBSP - Building Blocks Structure Predictor | Hybrid template-based || Free application plus database || [http://acbrc.org/ main page] |- |DeepFR | Remote template selection, 3D modeling || Improving protein fold recognition by extracting fold-specific features from predicted residue-residue contacts || [http://protein.ict.ac.cn/deepfr server] [https://github.com/zhujianwei31415/deepfr download] |} ===''Ab initio'' structure prediction=== {{main|De novo protein structure prediction}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center" |- ! Name ! Method || Description || Link |- | [[EVfold]] | Evolutionary couplings calculated from correlated mutations in a protein family, used to predict 3D structure from sequences alone and to predict functional residues from coupling strengths. Predicts both globular and transmembrane proteins. || Webserver || [http://evfold.org/ Server] |- |FALCON |A position-specific hidden Markov model to predict protein structure by iteratively refining the distributions of dihedral angles |Webserver |[https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18723665 article] [http://protein.ict.ac.cn/FALCON server] |- | [[QUARK]] | Monte Carlo fragment assembly || On-line server for protein modeling (best for ab initio folding in CASP9) || [http://zhanglab.ccmb.med.umich.edu/QUARK/ Server] |- | [[NovaFold]] | Combination of threading and ab initio folding || Commercial protein structure prediction application || [http://www.dnastar.com/t-products-NovaFold.aspx Home page] |- | [[I-TASSER]] | Threading fragment structure reassembly || On-line server for protein modeling || [http://zhanglab.ccmb.med.umich.edu/I-TASSER/ Server] [http://zhanglab.ccmb.med.umich.edu/I-TASSER/download download] |- | [[Selvita Protein Modeling Platform]] | Package of tools for protein modeling || Interactive webserver and standalone program including: CABS ab initio modeling || [http://www.selvita.com/selvita-protein-modeling-platform.html Home page] |- | [[Rosetta@home|ROBETTA]] | Rosetta homology modeling and ab initio fragment assembly with Ginzu domain prediction || Webserver || [https://web.archive.org/web/20150819163428/http://www.robetta.org/ server] |- | [[Rosetta@home]] | Distributed-computing implementation of Rosetta algorithm || Downloadable program || [http://boinc.bakerlab.org/rosetta/ main page] |- | CABS | Reduced modeling tool || Downloadable program || [https://web.archive.org/web/20121009080857/http://www.biocomp.chem.uw.edu.pl/services.php download] |- |CABS-FOLD |Server for de novo modeling, can also use alternative templates (consensus modeling).|| Webserver || [http://biocomp.chem.uw.edu.pl/CABSfold/ server] |- | Bhageerath | A computational protocol for modeling and predicting protein structures at the atomic level.|| Webserver|| [http://www.scfbio-iitd.res.in/bhageerath/index.jsp Server ] |- | [[Abalone (molecular mechanics)|Abalone]] | Molecular Dynamics folding || Program || [http://www.biomolecular-modeling.com/Abalone/Protein-folding.html Example] |- | PEP-FOLD | ''De novo'' approach, based on a HMM structural alphabet || On-line server for peptide structure prediction || [http://bioserv.rpbs.univ-paris-diderot.fr/PEP-FOLD/ Server ] |} ===Secondary structure prediction=== {{main|Protein structure prediction#Secondary structure}} Detailed list of programs can be found at [[List of protein secondary structure prediction programs]] ===Transmembrane helix prediction=== {{main|Transmembrane helix prediction}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center" |- ! Name ! Method || Description || Link |- | [[HMMTOP]] | [[Hidden Markov Model]] || Webserver/standalone || [http://www.enzim.hu/hmmtop/ main page] |- | [[MEMSAT]] | Neural networks and SVMs || Webserver/standalone || [http://bioinf.cs.ucl.ac.uk/psipred main page] |- | [[PHDhtm]] in [[Predictprotein|PredictProtein]] | Multiple alignment-based neural network system || Webserver/standalone || [http://www.predictprotein.org/ server] |- | [[Phobius]] | Homology supported predictions || Webserver/standalone || [http://phobius.sbc.su.se/ main page] |- | [[TMHMM]] | [[Hidden Markov Model]] || Webserver/standalone || [http://www.cbs.dtu.dk/services/TMHMM/ main page] |- | [[CCTOP]] | [[Consensus/Hidden Markov Model]] || Webserver/standalone || [http://cctop.enzim.ttk.mta.hu/ main page] |- | [[SVMTop2]] | [[Support Vector Machines]] || Webserver || [https://web.archive.org/web/20120502035214/http://bio-cluster.iis.sinica.edu.tw/SVMtop2/Submit.html main page] |} ===Signal peptide prediction=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center" |- ! Name ! Method || Description || Link |- | [[SignalP]] | [[artificial neural networks and hidden Markov models]] || Webserver/standalone || [http://www.cbs.dtu.dk/services/SignalP/ server] |} ==See also== *[[List of protein secondary structure prediction programs]] *[[Comparison of nucleic acid simulation software]] *[[List of software for molecular mechanics modeling]] *[[Molecular design software]] *[[Protein design]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Protein structure prediction software}} [[Category:Lists of software]] [[Category:Protein methods]] [[Category:Protein structure]] [[Category:Bioinformatics software]] [[Category:Proteomics]]

revision.comment: /* History */clean up; http→https for [[The Guardian]] using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox Radio show |show_name = Material World |image = |imagesize = |caption = |other_names = |format = Current science |runtime = 30 mins (Thursdays) |country = UK |language = English |home_station = BBC Radio 4 |syndicates = |television = |presenter = Quentin Cooper, [[Sue Nelson]] |starring = |announcer = |creator = |writer = |director = |senior_editor = |editor = |producer = |exec_producer = |narrated = |rec_location = |first_aired = 9 April 1998 |last_aired = 27 June 2013 |num_series = |num_episodes = |audio_format = |opentheme = |othertheme = |endtheme = |website = [http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b006qyyb Website] |podcast = [http://www.bbc.co.uk/podcasts/series/material/ Podcasts] }}
'''''Material World''''' was a weekly science magazine programme on [[BBC Radio 4]] broadcast on a Thursday afternoon. The programme's regular presenter was [[Quentin Cooper]], with contributions from scientists researching areas under discussion in each programme.
==History== The programme began as ''The Material World'' in April 1998. It was presented by [[Trevor Phillips]], a chemistry graduate of [[Imperial College London|Imperial College]]. In September 2000 Phillips was told that he could no longer work at the BBC due to his close links with the Labour Party, which broke BBC rules of impartiality. He was one of the few regular black broadcasters on Radio 4.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2000/sep/24/uk.labour1| title=BBC bans Trevor Phillips for political link| newspaper=[[The Guardian]]| date=24 September 2000| first=Kamal| last=Ahmed| author-link=Kamal Ahmed (journalist) |accessdate=12 October 2011}}</ref> The programme was presented by Quentin Cooper from 2000 to its end in 2013.
Material World was one of the BBC's main conduits for up-to-date scientific news, along with ''[[Frontiers (radio programme)|Frontiers]]'', ''[[Science in Action – BBC World Service Radio|Science in Action]]'', and ''[[Bang Goes the Theory]]''.
From 5 April 2010 the programme was repeated on a Monday evening at 21.00, in the former slot of ''[[Costing the Earth]]''. For a short time, when programmes on [[BBC Radio 5 Live|5 Live]] began [[Streaming media|webstreaming]] with video, ''Material World'' was also [[webcast]].
On 14 June 2013 it was announced that the show was to be cancelled, to be replaced by a new show, ''Inside Science''.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/radio4/posts/Introducing-Inside-Science |title = Introducing Inside Science |last = Bakaya |first = Mohit |date = 14 June 2013 |accessdate= 20 June 2013 }}</ref> The last programme presented by Quentin Cooper was broadcast on 20 June 2013 with the final episode airing a week later on 27 June 2013, presented by Gareth Mitchell.
==Structure== A typical episode programme covered three or four topics, giving each 7-10 minutes. For many years the programme was divided into two sections of fifteen minutes on separate topics.{{fact|date=September 2015}} It took the form of interviewing a guest scientist or engineer. Cooper often ended the programme with a terrible scientific [[pun]].
Many past programmes are available for online listening via the programme's website. Some sequential sets of programmes were made in collaboration with the [[Open University]].
==See also== * [[Association of British Science Writers]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b006qyyb BBC Radio 4's Material World official site] * [http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio4/science/thematerialworld_archive.shtml BBC Radio 4's Material World Archive page] * [http://www3.open.ac.uk/media/fullstory.aspx?id=11546 Co-operation with the Open University] * [http://www.open2.net/materialworld/index.html Assistance with the Open University] * [http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio4/features/sywtbas/ So You Want To Be A Scientist?]

/* Multi-Stakeholder Models */
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2014}} {{Governance}}
The '''multistakeholder governance model''', sometimes known as a '''multistakeholder initiative''' ('''MSI'''),<ref>Utting, P. (2001). [http://www.people.fas.harvard.edu/~hiscox/Utting.pdf "Regulating Business Via Multistakeholder Initiatives: A Preliminary Assessment."] (Paper prepared in late 2001 under the United Nations Research Institute for Social Development (UNRISD) research project "Promoting Corporate Environmental and Social Responsibility in Developing Countries: The Potential and Limits of Voluntary Initiatives".) Accessed 14/May/2014</ref><ref>Fuchs, D., Kalfagianni, A., & Havinga, T. (2011) "Actors in private food governance: the legitimacy of retail standards and multistakeholder initiatives with civil society participation", Agriculture and Human Values , September 2011, Volume 28, Issue 3, pp 353-367.</ref> is a governance structure that seeks to bring [[stakeholder (corporate)|stakeholder]]s together to participate in the dialogue, decision making, and implementation of solutions to common problems or goals. The principle behind such a structure is that if enough input is provided by all actors involved in a question, the eventual consensual decision gains more legitimacy, and therefore better reflects a set of perspectives rather than a single source of validation.
A [[Project stakeholder|stakeholder]] refers to an individual, group, or organization that has a direct or indirect interest or stake in a particular organization, these may be businesses, [[civil society]], governments, research institutions, and non-government organizations.
==Multi-Stakeholder Models==
The multistakeholder model is used in Internet governance by entities such as the [[ICANN]] and [[IETF]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Internet Society Questionnaire on Multistakeholder Governance Report and Summary of the Results. October 2013|url=http://www.internetsociety.org/doc/internet-society-questionnaire-multistakeholder-governance-report-and-summary-results-october|publisher=Internet Society|accessdate=13 March 2014}}</ref> It has been the foundation of local governance entities such as [[Community boards of New York City|New York City's Community Boards]].
Norbert Bollow, co-coordinator on the Civil Society Internet Governance Forum<ref>http://www.igcaucus.org/</ref> distinguishes between "representative" multistakeholderism, using as examples the United Nation's [https://www.intgovforum.org/multilingual/content/about-mag MAG] and ECWG, in which a limited number of seats are distributed to representatives through some selection process, and "open" multistakeholderism, as represented by the IETF and RIRs, which relies on participants self-selecting to balance perspectives.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading==
* Introduction To The ICANN Multi-Stakeholder Model http://toronto45.icann.org/meetings/toronto2012/presentation-multi-stakeholder-model-14oct12-en.pdf * http://www.igfwatch.org/discussion-board/a-civil-society-agenda-for-internet-governance-in-2013-internet-freedom-in-a-world-of-states-part-3 * [https://gurstein.wordpress.com/2013/03/20/multistakeholderism-vs-democracy-my-adventures-in-stakeholderland/ Multistakeholderism vs. Democracy: My Adventures in "Stakeholderland" by Michael Gurstein] * [http://www.internetsociety.org/blog/2013/05/multistakeholder-cooperation-reflections-emergence-new-phraseology-international Multistakeholder Cooperation: Reflections on the emergence of a new phraseology in international cooperation by Marcus Kummer]
[[Category:Organizational culture]] [[Category:Political science]] [[Category:Public policy]]

revision.text:
The '''Newbury Principles''' collectively refer to an [[urban planning]] guideline stating that decisions should be made based only on the planning considerations relevant to the current development, even if the consideration of ulterior purposes may lead to a greater public good. In practice, the principles are used as a test to verify the validity of conditions to be imposed by a planning authority.
Specifically, the decision of the [[Judicial functions of the House of Lords|House of Lords]] in ''Newbury District Council v Secretary of State for the Environment'',<ref>''Newbury District Council v Secretary of State for the Environment'' [1981] [[Appeal Cases Law Reports|AC]] 578.</ref> contains the following three principles when considering the reasonableness of imposing conditions on consents:
# It must be imposed for a planning purpose. # It must fairly and reasonably relate to the development for which permission is being given. # It must be reasonable.
The Newbury principles are applied in [[Australia]], and have been cited by courts in [[New South Wales]] and [[Western Australia]].<ref>[http://www.austlii.edu.au/cgi-bin/LawCite?cit=1981+AC+578 LawCite records].</ref><ref>For example: *{{cite web | title =245 Bobbin Head Road, Turramurra | publisher =[[Ku-ring-gai Council]] | date =15 November 2006 | url =http://www.kmc.nsw.gov.au/resources/documents/rptomc5Dec06GB.02.pdf | accessdate = 2007-05-14 }} *{{cite web | title =40 Premier Street, Neutral Bay | publisher =[[North Sydney Council]] | date =27 November 2006 | url =http://www.northsydney.nsw.gov.au/resources/documents/PDS1051.pdf | accessdate = 2007-05-14 }} *{{cite AustLII|WASCA|181|2016|litigants=Reid v Western Australian Planning Commission |date=24 October 2016 |courtname=auto}}.</ref> The Newbury test also remains in general application in the courts of [[New Zealand]].<ref>For example:{{cite web |title = 306 Jackson Street, Petone |publisher = Hutt River Council |date = 21 February 2006 |url = http://www.huttcity.info/council/about/governance/meetings/standing/operations-compliance/m114075281/reports/Hearingofapplicationforreviewofsubdivision306JacksonStreet.pdf |accessdate = 2007-05-14 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070928051727/http://www.huttcity.info/council/about/governance/meetings/standing/operations-compliance/m114075281/reports/Hearingofapplicationforreviewofsubdivision306JacksonStreet.pdf |archivedate = 28 September 2007 |df = }}</ref> ==Notes== {{Reflist}} == References == * {{cite book | title = The Environmental Law Handbook : Planning and Land Use in NSW, 4th Edition | author = David Farrier |author2=Paul Stein | publisher = Redfern Legal Centre | location = Sydney | year = 2006 | edition= 4th | pages = 748 pages }}
==External links== * [http://www.kmc.nsw.gov.au/resources/documents/rptomc5Dec06GB.02.pdf Example invocation of the Newbury principles for a development application], Ku-ring-gai council report, Nov. 15, 2006. * [http://www.northsydney.nsw.gov.au/resources/documents/PDS1051.pdf A more detailed example] Report to the General Manager, North Sydney Council, Nov. 21., 2006. * [https://www.northsydney.nsw.gov.au/files/assets/public/docs/1_council_meetings/committees/legal_planning_committee/september_2013/lp05_da_conditions_of_consent_review.pdf Review of DA Conditions, Legal and Planning Committee Sep 2013] Report to the General Manager, North Sydney Council, Sept 23, 2013 * [http://www.woollahra.nsw.gov.au/building_and_development/development_applications/consents/conditions Woollahra Municipal Council - Conditions in development application consents]
[[Category:Urban planning]]
