revision.text:
'''Socioemotional selectivity theory''' ('''SST'''; developed by Stanford psychologist [[Laura L. Carstensen]]) is a life-span theory of motivation. The theory maintains that as time horizons shrink, as they typically do with age, people become increasingly selective, investing greater resources in emotionally meaningful goals and activities. According to the theory, motivational shifts also influence cognitive processing. Aging is associated with a relative preference for positive over negative information in attention and memory (called the "[[positivity effect]]").
==Overview== Because they place a high value on emotional satisfaction, older adults often spend more time with familiar individuals with whom they have had rewarding relationships.<ref name="Santrock">Santrock, J.W. (2008). ''A Topical Approach to Life-Span Development''. New York, NY: McGraw-Hill.{{page needed|date=February 2015}}</ref> This selective narrowing of social interaction maximizes positive emotional experiences and minimizes emotional risks as individuals become older. According to this theory, older adults systematically hone their social networks so that available social partners satisfy their emotional needs.<ref name="Santrock"/>
The theory also focuses on the types of goals that individuals are motivated to achieve. Knowledge-related goals aim at knowledge acquisition, career planning, the development of new social relationships and other endeavors that will pay off in the future. Emotion-related goals are aimed at emotion regulation, the pursuit of emotionally gratifying interactions with social partners and other pursuits whose benefits can be realized in the present.
When people perceive their future as open ended, they tend to focus on future-oriented and development- or knowledge-related goals, but when they feel that time is running out and the opportunity to reap rewards from future-oriented goals' realization is dwindling, their focus tends to shift towards present-oriented and emotion- or pleasure-related goals.<ref name="Santrock"/> Research on this theory often compares age groups (''e.g.'', young adulthood vs. old adulthood), but the shift in goal priorities is a gradual process that begins in early adulthood. Importantly, the theory contends that the cause of these goal shifts is not age itself, ''i.e.'', not the passage of time itself, but rather an age-associated shift in time perspective.<ref name="Santrock"/>
This justified shift in perspective is the rational equivalent of the psychological perceptual disorder known as "foreshortened future," in which an individual, usually a young and physically healthy individual, unreasonably believes (either consciously or unconsciously) that his/her time horizons are more limited than they actually are, with the effect that the individual undervalues long-term goals and long-run pleasure and instead disproportionately pursues short-term goals and pleasure, thereby [[Opportunity cost|diverting resources from investment for the future]] and often even actively reducing his/her long-term prospects.
==Cross-cultural incidence== Researchers have found that across diverse samples – ranging from [[Norwegian people|Norwegian]]s to [[Catholic nun]]s to [[African-American]]s to [[Chinese American]]s{{clarify|date=February 2013}} to [[European-American]]s – older adults report better control of their emotions and fewer negative emotions than do younger adults.<ref name="Santrock"/> At the same time, culture seems to color how aging-related effects impact one's emotional life: Whereas older Americans were shown to de-emphasize negative experiences more than younger Americans, no such effect has been observed in Japan. Instead, older Japanese were shown to assign a greater value to positive aspects of otherwise negative experiences than younger Japanese, whereas no such effect has been observed in the U.S.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1037/a0036041|pmid=24749641|title=A cultural perspective on emotional experiences across the life span|journal=Emotion|volume=14|issue=4|pages=679|year=2014|last1=Grossmann|first1=Igor|last2=Karasawa|first2=Mayumi|last3=Kan|first3=Chiemi|last4=Kitayama|first4=Shinobu}}</ref>
==Positivity effect in older adults==
=== In perception === Studies have found that older adults are more likely than younger adults to pay attention to positive than negative stimuli (as assessed by the [[dot-probe paradigm]] and eye-tracking methods). However, the effect also differs across cultures. For example, Hong Kong Chinese looked away from happy stimuli and more towards fearful stimuli,<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Fung | first1 = H. H. | last2 = Lu | first2 = A. Y. | last3 = Goren | first3 = D. | last4 = Isaacowitz | first4 = D. M. | last5 = Wadlinger | first5 = | last6 = Wilson | first6 = H. R. | year = 2008 | title = Age-related positivity enhancement is not universal: older Chinese look away from positive stimuli | url = | journal = Psychology and Aging | volume = 23 | issue = 2| pages = 440–6 | doi = 10.1037/0882-7974.23.2.440 | pmid = 18573017 }}</ref> and the difference in attention pattern was related to differences in self-construal.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Fung | first1 = H. H. | last2 = Isaacowitz | first2 = D. M. | last3 = Lu | first3 = A. Y. | last4 = Li | first4 = T. | year = 2010 | title = Interdependent self-construal moderates the age-related negativity reduction effect in memory and visual attention | url = | journal = Psychology and Aging | volume = 25 | issue = 2| pages = 321–9 | doi = 10.1037/a0019079 | pmid = 20545417 }}</ref>
=== In recall === The term ''positivity effect'' also refers to age differences in emotional attention and memory. As people get older, they experience fewer negative emotions and they tend to look to the past in a positive light.{{sfn|Mather|Carstensen|2005}} In addition, compared with younger adults' memories, older adults' memories are more likely to consist of positive than negative information and more likely to be distorted in a positive direction. This version of the positivity effect was coined by Laura L. Carstensen's research team.<ref name="Carstensen2006">{{cite journal|last1=Carstensen|first1=L. L.|title=The Influence of a Sense of Time on Human Development|journal=Science|date=2006|volume=312|issue=5782|pages=1913–1915|doi=10.1126/science.1127488|pmid=16809530|pmc=2790864|bibcode=2006Sci...312.1913C}}</ref> There is a debate about the cross-cultural generalizability of the aging-related positivity effect, with some evidence for different types of emotional processing among Americans as compared to Japanese.<ref>{{cite journal|title=A cultural perspective on emotional experiences across the life span|journal=Emotion|date=2014|doi=10.1037/a0036041 |pmid=24749641 |volume=14 |issue=4|pages=679–92|last1=Grossmann|first1=I|last2=Karasawa|first2=M|last3=Kan|first3=C|last4=Kitayama|first4=S}}</ref>
====Hypothesized causes==== One theory of the positivity effect in older adults' memories is that it is produced by cognitive control mechanisms that improve and decrease negative information due to older adults' greater focus on emotional regulation.{{sfn|Mather|Carstensen|2005}} Research shows an age-related reversal in the valence of information processed within the [[medial prefrontal cortex]] (MPFC). In younger adults, more MPFC activity was found in the presence of negative stimuli compared to positive stimuli whereas in older adults this was reversed.{{citation needed|date=April 2013}}
However, the positivity effect may be different for stimuli processed automatically (pictures) and stimuli processed in a more controlled manner (words). Compared to words, pictures tend to be processed more rapidly and they engage emotion processing centres earlier. Automatic stimuli are processed in the [[amygdala]] and dorsal MPFC, whereas controlled stimuli are processed in the temporal pole and ventral MPFC. Compared to younger adults, older adults showed less amygdala activation and more MPFC activation for negative than positive pictures. Increased motivation to regulate emotion leads older adults to actively engage the mPFC differently from younger adults, which in turn yields diverging amygdala activation patterns.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 18455837| pmc = 3541693| year = 2010| last1 = St. Jacques| first1 = P| title = Effects of aging on functional connectivity of the amygdala during negative evaluation: A network analysis of fMRI data| journal = Neurobiology of Aging| volume = 31| issue = 2| pages = 315–327| last2 = Dolcos| first2 = F| last3 = Cabeza| first3 = R| doi = 10.1016/j.neurobiolaging.2008.03.012}}</ref> The opposite pattern was observed for words. Although older adults showed a positivity effect in memory for words, they did not display one for pictures. Thus, the positivity effect may arise from ageing differences in MPFC use during encoding.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Leclerc | first1 = C. | last2 = Kensinger | first2 = E. | year = 2011 | title = Neural processing of emotional pictures and words: A comparison of young and older adults | url = | journal = Developmental Neuropsychology | volume = 36 | issue = 4| pages = 519–538 | doi = 10.1080/87565641.2010.549864 | pmid = 21516546 }}</ref>
== See also == *[[Aging and memory]] *[[Negativity bias]] *[[Positivity effect]]
==References== <references/>
== Sources == *{{cite journal |pmid=1340521|year=1992|author1=Carstensen|first1=L. L.|title=Motivation for social contact across the life span: A theory of socioemotional selectivity|journal=Nebraska Symposium on Motivation |volume=40|pages=209–54|ref=harv}} *{{cite journal |doi=10.1037/0003-066X.54.3.165|pmid=10199217|title=Taking time seriously: A theory of socioemotional selectivity|journal=American Psychologist|volume=54|issue=3|pages=165|year=1999|last1=Carstensen|first1=Laura L.|last2=Isaacowitz|first2=Derek M.|last3=Charles|first3=Susan T.|ref=harv}} *{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.tics.2005.08.005|pmid=16154382|title=Aging and motivated cognition: The positivity effect in attention and memory|journal=Trends in Cognitive Sciences|volume=9|issue=10|pages=496|year=2005|last1=Mather|first1=Mara|last2=Carstensen|first2=Laura L.|ref=harv| url = http://matherlab.usc.edu/pdfs/MatherCarstensen2005.pdf}} *{{cite journal Choices|journal=Journal of Personality|volume=72|issue=6|pages=1395|year=2004|last1=Lockenhoff|first1=Corinna E.|last2=Carstensen|first2=Laura L.|ref=harv}} *{{cite journal |doi=10.1037/0882-7974.19.1.68|pmid=15065932|title=Motivational Changes in Response to Blocked Goals and Foreshortened Time: Testing Alternatives to Socioemotional Selectivity Theory|journal=Psychology and Aging|volume=19|issue=1|pages=68–78|year=2004|last1=Fung|first1=Helene H.|last2=Carstensen|first2=Laura L.|ref=harv}} *{{cite journal |doi=10.1046/j.1467-9507.2006.00344.x|title=An Attentional Application of Socioemotional Selectivity Theory in College Students|journal=Social Development|volume=15|issue=2|pages=326|year=2006|last1=Pruzan|first1=Katherine|last2=Isaacowitz|first2=Derek M.|ref=harv}} *{{cite journal |bibcode=2006Sci...312.1913C|title=The Influence of a Sense of Time on Human Development|journal=Science|volume=312|issue=5782|pages=1913–5|author1=Carstensen|first1=Laura L.|year=2006|doi=10.1126/science.1127488|pmid=16809530|pmc=2790864|ref=harv}} *{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.0963-7214.2005.00348.x|title=At the Intersection of Emotion and Cognition. Aging and the Positivity Effect|journal=Current Directions in Psychological Science|volume=14|issue=3|pages=117|year=2005|last1=Carstensen|first1=Laura L.|last2=Mikels|first2=Joseph A.|ref=harv}} *{{cite journal|pmc=3459016|year=2012|last1=Reed|first1=A. E.|title=The Theory Behind the Age-Related Positivity Effect|journal=Frontiers in Psychology|volume=3|pages=339|last2=Carstensen|first2=L. L.|doi=10.3389/fpsyg.2012.00339|pmid=23060825|ref=harv}}

revision.text:
'''Universal conductance fluctuations''' '''(UCF)''' in [[mesoscopic physics]] is a phenomenon encountered in electrical transport experiments in [[mesoscopic physics|mesoscopic]] species. The measured electrical [[Electrical conductance|conductance]] will vary from sample to sample, mainly due to inhomogeneous scattering sites. Fluctuations originate from coherence effects for electronic wavefunctions and thus the phase-coherence length <math>\textstyle l_\phi</math> needs be larger than the momentum relaxation length <math>\textstyle l_m</math>. UCF is more profound when electrical transport is in [[weak localization]] regime. <math>\textstyle l_\phi<l_c</math> where <math>l_c=M\cdot l_m</math> , <math>\textstyle M</math> is the number of conduction channels and <math>\textstyle l_m</math>is the momentum relaxation due to phonon scattering events length or mean free path. For weakly localized samples fluctuation in conductance is equal to fundamental conductance <math>\textstyle G_o=2e^2/h</math> regardless of the number of channels.
Many factors will influence the amplitude of UCF. At zero temperature without decoherence, the UCF is influenced by mainly two factors, the symmetry and the shape of the sample. Recently, a third key factor, anisotropy of Fermi surface, is also found to fundamentally influence the amplitude of UCF.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hu|first=Yayun|last2=Liu|first2=Haiwen|last3=Jiang|first3=Hua|last4=Xie|first4=X. C.|date=2017-10-05|title=Numerical study of universal conductance fluctuations in three-dimensional topological semimetals|url=https://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevB.96.134201|journal=Physical Review B|volume=96|issue=13|pages=134201|doi=10.1103/PhysRevB.96.134201|arxiv=1708.05212|bibcode=2017PhRvB..96m4201H}}</ref> == See also ==
* [[Speckle pattern]]s, the optical analogues of conductance fluctuation patterns.
== References == {{reflist}} <!-- which page referred is vague *[http://www.nanohub.org nanoHUB website] -->
=== General references ===
* Akkermans and Montambaux, ''Mesoscopic Physics of Electrons and Photons'', Cambridge University Press (2007) * [[Supriyo Datta]], ''Electronic Transport in Mesoscopic Systems'', Cambridge University Press (1995) * R. Saito, G. Dresselhaus and [[Mildred Dresselhaus|M. S. Dresselhaus]], ''Physical Properties of Carbon Nanotubes'', Imperial College Press (1998) * {{Cite journal | last1 = Lee | first1 = P. | last2 = Stone | first2 = A. | title = Universal Conductance Fluctuations in Metals | journal = Physical Review Letters | volume = 55 | issue = 15 | pages = 1622–1625 | year = 1985 | pmid = 10031872 | doi = 10.1103/PhysRevLett.55.1622| bibcode=1985PhRvL..55.1622L}} * [[Boris Altshuler]] (1985), Pis'ma Zh. Eksp. Teor. Fiz. '''41''': 530 [JETP Lett. '''41''': 648] .
[[Category:Mesoscopic physics]] [[Category:Quantum mechanics]]

revision.text:
'''William Griffith McBride''' [[Commander of the Order of the British Empire|CBE]] [[Officer of the Order of Australia|AO]] (25 May 1927 – 27 June 2018) was an [[Australia]]n [[obstetrician]]. He discovered the [[Teratology|teratogenicity]] of [[thalidomide]],<ref>[http://catalogue.nla.gov.au/Record/1501964 Papers of William McBride, ca. 1953-1996], [[National Library of Australia]], accessed 26 July 2010</ref><ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/archives/timeline/1960s.htm 1960s Timeline] — [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]]</ref><ref>Page 48 of ''[[The New Scientist]]'', Page 48, Vol. 56 — published 5 October 1972</ref><ref>Dove, Frederick. [https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-19448046 Thalidomide apology insulting, campaigners say] [[BBC News]] 1 September 2012. Accessed 31 March 2017</ref> which resulted in the reduction of the number of drugs prescribed during [[pregnancy]].
==Biography== McBride was born in [[Sydney]], [[New South Wales]], [[Australia]].<ref>[http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2002/06/20/1023864476347.html The most influential Australians] — ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]''</ref><ref>[http://www.asap.unimelb.edu.au/bsparcs/biogs/P002020b.htm William Griffith McBride biography] — The University of Melbourne</ref>
===Thalidomide case=== Dr McBride published a letter in ''[[The Lancet]]'', in December 1961, noting a large number of [[birth defect]]s in children of patients who were prescribed thalidomide,<ref>McCredie, Janet. [http://blogs.usyd.edu.au/sydneypublishing/2014/01/the_thalidomide_story.html The thalidomide story]. Sydney Publishing ([[University of Sydney]]), 17 January 2016</ref> after a [[midwife]] first suspected the drug was causing birth defects in the babies of patients under his care at [[Crown Street Women's Hospital]] in Sydney.<ref>http://www.abc.net.au/news/health/2018-06-29/thalidomide-william-mcbride-flawed-character-norman-swan/9920608</ref> Dr. McBride was awarded a medal and prize money by the prestigious [http://www.mauricemarois.fr/les-prix/ L'Institut de la Vie], a French Institute, in connection with his discovery, in 1971. Using the prize money, he established [[Foundation 41]], a Sydney-based medical research foundation concerned with the causes of birth defects. Working with Dr P H Huang, he proposed that thalidomide caused malformations by interacting with the DNA of the dividing embryonic cells. This finding stimulated their experimentation, which showed that thalidomide may inhibit cell division in rapidly dividing cells of malignant tumors. This work was published in the journal "Pharmacology and Toxicology" in 1999 and has been rated in the top ten of the most important Australian medical discoveries.{{cn|date=July 2018}} <!-- ([[The Sydney Morning Herald]] - 2005) is not specific enough -->
===Debendox case=== McBride's involvement in the Debendox case is less illustrious.<ref>{{cite book |author=Grant J |title=Corrupted Science| publisher= Facts, Figures & Fun |year=2007 |isbn=978-1-904332-73-2 |page=49f}}</ref> In 1981 he published a paper indicating that the drug [[Debendox]] (marketed in the US as [[Bendectin]]) caused birth defects. His co-authors noted that the published paper contained manipulated data and protested<ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/austory/transcripts/s248519.htm The Insider], ''[[Australian Story]]'', 22 February 2001, accessed 26 July 2010</ref> but their voices went unheard. Multiple lawsuits followed by patients and McBride was a willing witness for the claimants. Eventually, the case was investigated and, as a result, McBride was struck off the Australian medical register in 1993 for deliberately falsifying data.<ref>[https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg13718620.800-thalidomide-hero-found-guilty-of-scientific-fraud-.html Thalidomide hero found guilty of scientific fraud] — ''[[The New Scientist]]'', 27 February 1991</ref> An inquiry determined "we are forced to conclude that Dr. McBride did publish statements which he either knew were untrue or which he did not genuinely believe to be true, and in that respect was guilty of scientific fraud." He was reinstated to the medical register in 1998.<ref>[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,33714,00.html "''Time Magazine''"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090903082456/http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,33714,00.html |date=3 September 2009 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.nswmb.org.au/system/files/f10/f28/o559//William%20McBride.9.pdf Medical Tribunal of New South Wales] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090920110206/http://www.nswmb.org.au/system/files/f10/f28/o559/William%20McBride.9.pdf |date=20 September 2009 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,25253506-5006784,00.html Dr. McBride hails end of the affair] — "''The Australian''"</ref>
The Bendectin case, and the subsequent removal of the drug from the US market, has had a number of consequences.<ref name=":5">Brent R. "Medical, social, and legal implications of treating nausea and vomiting of pregnancy" ''Am J Obstet Gynecol'' 2002 May;186(5 Suppl Understanding):S262-6</ref> Firstly, there was an immediate increase in the rates of hospitalization for nausea and vomiting in pregnancy.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Kutcher | first1 = JS | last2 = Engle | first2 = A | last3 = Firth | first3 = J | last4 = Lamm | first4 = SH | year = 2003 | title = Bendectin and birth defects. II: Ecological analyses | url = | journal = Birth Defects Research | volume = 67 | issue = 2| pages = 88–97 | doi = 10.1002/bdra.10034 | pmid = 12769504 }}</ref> Secondly, it created a treatment void in terms of having a safe medication that could be used for alleviating morning sickness in US pregnant women, a condition which, in the most severe form, called [[hyperemesis gravidarum]], could be both life-threatening and cause women to terminate their pregnancy.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Mazzotta | first1 = P | last2 = Stewart | first2 = DE | last3 = Koren | first3 = G | last4 = Magee | first4 = LA | date = Mar 2001 | title = Factors associated with elective termination of pregnancy among Canadian and American women with nausea and vomiting of pregnancy | url = | journal = J Psychosom Obstet Gynaecol | volume = 22 | issue = 1| pages = 7–12 | doi=10.3109/01674820109049946}}</ref>
The lack of availability of a safe and effective drug for the treatment of nausea and vomiting of pregnancy resulted in the use of other, less studied drugs in pregnancy.<ref name=":5" /><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Leeder | first1 = JS | last2 = Spielberg | first2 = SP | last3 = MacLeod | first3 = SM | date = Nov 1983 | title = Bendectin: the wrong way to regulate drug availability | url = | journal = Can Med Assoc J | volume = 129 | issue = 10| pages = 1085–7 }}</ref><ref>Mitchell AA, Gilboa SM, Werler MM, Kelley KE, Louik C, Hernández-Díaz S; National Birth Defects Prevention Study. Medication use during pregnancy, with particular focus on prescription drugs: 1976-2008" ''Am J Obstet Gynecol'' 2011 Jul;205(1):51.e1-8</ref> Thirdly, it has been claimed that subsequent to the Bendectin experience, drug companies stayed away from developing medications for pregnant patients.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Wing | first1 = DA | last2 = Powers | first2 = B | last3 = Hickok | first3 = D | year = 2010 | title = U.S. Food and Drug Administration Drug Approval: Slow Advances in Obstetric Care in the United States | url = | journal = Obstetrics & Gynecology | volume = 115 | issue = 4| pages = 825–33 | doi = 10.1097/AOG.0b013e3181d53843 | pmid = 20308845 }}</ref> As a result, only a few medications were approved by the FDA for obstetrical indications in the past several decades.<ref>Centerwatch. FDA Approved Drugs for Obstetrics/Gynecology (Women’s Health); as seen in: <nowiki>https://www.centerwatch.com/drug-information/fda-approved-drugs/therapeutic-area/11/obstetrics-gynecology-womens-health</nowiki></ref> Lastly, the perception that all medications are teratogenic increased among pregnant women and healthcare professionals.<ref name=":6">{{cite journal | last1 = Koren | first1 = G | last2 = Levichek | first2 = Z | date = May 2002 | title = The teratogenicity of drugs for nausea and vomiting of pregnancy: perceived versus true risk | url = | journal = Am J Obstet Gynecol | volume = 186 | issue = 5 Suppl | pages = S248–52 }}</ref> The unfounded fear of using medications during pregnancy has precluded many women from receiving the treatment they require.<ref name=":6" /> Leaving medical conditions untreated during pregnancy can result in adverse pregnancy outcomes or significant morbidity for both the mother and baby.<ref name=":6" /> Ongoing education of physicians and the general public has resulted in improvements in the perception of medication use in pregnancy; however, further advances are required to overcome the devastating effects of the Bendectin saga.<ref name=":5" />
===Honours=== Dr McBride was nominated Man of the Year for 1962,<ref>"Saviour of babies—The Man of the Year" - Article published on page 1 of ''[[The Daily Mirror (Sydney)]]'', Sydney, Friday, 28 December 1962.</ref> Commander of the [[Order of the British Empire]] (1969),<ref>[http://www.itsanhonour.gov.au/honours/honour_roll/search.cfm?aus_award_id=1065357&search_type=simple&showInd=true It's an Honour: CBE]</ref> Father of the Year (1972) and Officer of the [[Order of Australia]] (1977).<ref>[http://www.itsanhonour.gov.au/honours/honour_roll/search.cfm?aus_award_id=883733&search_type=simple&showInd=true It's an Honour: AO]</ref><ref>"[https://books.google.com/books?id=NVw_lEjArkgC&pg=PA92&lpg=PA92&dq=thalidomide+mcbride+prize&source=bl&ots=hTtawra2MC&sig=1CV_s8U5hC3JCx17Eu7H8qxygFc&hl=en&ei=9kuOSaibO5iq6wOc_7G7Cg&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=9&ct=result#PPA92,M1 Book: The Trouble with Medicine]"</ref>
===Death=== McBride died, aged 91, on 27 June 2018.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-06-28/william-mcbride-dies-aged-91/9919530 |title=William McBride, doctor who exposed dangers of thalidomide, dies |date=28 June 2018 |work=ABC News |accessdate=28 June 2018}}</ref> == See also == * [[List of scientific misconduct incidents]]
